author: {'steamid': '76561199007001650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 966, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1712432643}
review: I don't usually review anything. That said I struggle a lot with a lot of language learning apps *coughs* duo :/ shmingo. I've tried probably 20 different programs for learning Japanese at this point and they have all sucked because they have all focused on micro transactions or something else which took priority away from them having the learner actually commit the information to memory. I learned all of hiragana and most of kanji already through duo and then promptly forgot all of it due to it not having me do anything to practice it/no real game play, while still charging me 13$ a month. This probably won't be an interesting play for everyone. It's a stardew graphic style with Pokemon style fighting i think, but you learn Japanese in the process and to me it's phenomenal. It's helping me remember so much better than anything else I've used prior. I appreciate the people who made this game so much. I think it's a wonderful resource for beginners. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561199139245260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 196, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1711893291}
review: Brilliant way to learn Hiragana! Love the vocab lessons that give you some feeling of more progression. Of course, practice is always needed, so this is best as a teacher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061867271', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1711271220}
review:
I want it a game I could learn or you could say remember the Hiragana again. This game is very educational by showing you how to write and pronounce them. Also, it has grammar and vocabulary to get the aspects of the language. Of course, you need to practise on paper too.

The game has the typical story where you need to save your world by the villain who invaded your country. It was really fun and enjoyable as I was able to learn Hiragana.

The only thing I didn't like... I couldn't go on some cities, they were only for decoration, unfortunately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198323641851', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1710840966}
review:
冲着玩游戏可以学日语的噱头来的，如果零基础的话感觉还是有点用的，只限于学习五十音图的阶段，已经熟悉了的可以跳过了
作为一个学习游戏来看，它居然有剧情！！！虽然剧情一般且比较中二，但至少可以在学习过程中不那么枯燥，战斗也算有意思，根据凭空出现的平假名/罗马音（反正是游戏我也不追究为什么走在路上会冒出几个平假名出来揍我的事情了）选择对应的罗马音/平假名进行攻击，否则攻击无效，还是蛮巧妙的设计的。主线基本只会教你五十音图加上进阶的浊音和半浊音，并且每学一个段还会有一次考核，一些支线会教你一些比较简单的日用单词，你说记不住？记不住就挨打！死着死着就会了（
如果是真的零基础想从五十音学起的话可以一玩，学过的只会被游戏那地雷式的踩怪恶心到，走两步一个怪而且数值还贼高，不练级随便一个平假名都能把你秒了，想逃课？给我好好的去刷课！所以不建议有基础的玩，但说实话零基础的图个新鲜感玩还是可以的，但效率真不如去看个半小时视频，比这两小时的游戏时长有用多了，不过因为游戏没汉化的原因，拿来学嘤语也是不错的~

author: {'steamid': '76561198055354412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1710814737}
review:
So far, so good.  The game runs like an old school, turn based RPG.  You fight hiragana by guessing correctly what it means.  
I think the people who are criticizing this game were expecting too much from it.  I just bought all 3 games, plus the DLCs and didn't even break a 20.  Most language courses are really expensive.  These games are not meant to replace a full language course.  This is just a great memorization game for people who like RPGs.  
I definitely think they could improve upon the battle system.  I appreciate that it remembers the last option in a fight.  It would also be good if we could have all the characters choose the same answer with one step, instead of having all of them pick separately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064632162', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1709733774}
review:
Отличная вещь для тех, кто начинает учить японский.
Эта игра помогла мне выучить хирагану и несколько десятков слов.

Единственный минус это отсутствие случайности в битвах: группы врагов (знаков и слов) не меняются со временем – зная одного из них, можно вспомнить остальных, не напрягаясь.

Ну и с достижениями играть было бы ещё интереснее.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117924716', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1707047665}
review:
The lessons themselves are great. But having to pull out my inner RPG Player in me to play the game at a decent pace shouldn't be required. Don't add GRINDING and EQUIPMENT and FUCKING ONE WAY DUNGEONS to your EDUCATIONAL LANGUAGE GAME!!

Other than that, good lessons, would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026641143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1709501694}
review:
3/10 - As a game, it's awful. As an educational resource, it's a little less than mediocre. Recommended for kids aged 6-9 or for people who REALLY need to have some kind of other activity to motivate them in their language learning journey.

And now... wamekitateru...

GAMEPLAY
This isn't the type of game you buy for gameplay. That doesn't excuse the gameplay being tedious and boring with clunky interfaces, godawful combat, a godawful world map, borderline pointless side quests, and a bare bones RPG experience, but it does mean the game has to BRING IT as an educational resource to be in any way valuable.

EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE
And... as an educational resource... it doesn't exactly fail, but it also isn't amazing. The primary goal of this game is to teach you the Japanese hirigana writing system, and for the most part, it does that. Mostly through repetition. Lots, and lots, and lots of repetition. It's exactly the same type of repetition you'd get through using flash cards, in fact. So... why not just use flash cards? There is nothing you can get from this game that you can't get from any other resource that teaches the hirigana writing system.

The battles themselves aren't completely worthless, as they do give you repetition that can help you learn the hirigana, but I don't think the battles/repetition are as effective as they could be. As you wander around the map, you engage in random encounters with hirigana that you must get correctly. The problem is that there are maybe six or seven groups of 2-4 hirigana that you encounter on any given map, always in the same groups with the same other hirigana, and it rarely mixes it up by throwing in characters from earlier lessons. Add to this that the responses you give are always listed in the same order and you can pretty much just muscle memory some of the answers by remembering where they are on the chart rather than actually learning that the symbol stands for "ne" or "no" or whatever syllable it's supposed to be teaching you.

There are also some side lessons that can teach you Japanese vocabulary, but they exist more as study resources until the godawful endgame. There are no quizzes for the Japanese vocabulary lessons, and aside from a few side quests where they are actually important, you are almost never encouraged to engage with them through the gameplay. (Having to go to a shop to buy a manga and having all the shop's items written in hirigana was a notable exception, as it was VERY effective and something this game desperately needed more of.) Yes, the game presents you with the information, but it does almost nothing to help you learn that information. You'd get the same impact, again, from flash cards, or just buying a Japanese/English dictionary and practicing through repetition. There is no point to putting information in A GAME if the gameplay is going to do nothing to help you learn the information. The literal purpose of an educational game is to teach THROUGH GAMEPLAY.

THE GODAWFUL ENDGAME
Which brings me to the godawful endgame. Up to the endgame, the gameplay has focused on teaching you hirigana through repetition. Not necessarily ineffective, but very boring. It presents the hirigana and expects you to translate a single syllable into romanji, or it presents the romanji and expects you to translate it into hirigana. Aside from a handful of dull side quests which occasionally have you engage in a more meaningful way and lessons that show you Japanese words, and then don't have you do anything with that information, this is the gameplay. 

Until the endgame. You are now expected to translate words written in hirigana... directly into English. I cannot overemphasize how awful this endgame is. Should you learn the basic Japanese words it's presenting you with if you want to learn Japanese? Yes. It's kind of a requirement. But THE GAME did NOTHING to help you get to that point aside from showing you the words and saying, "Study these on your own." Not only that... but the whole purpose of this game... IS TO TEACH YOU HIRIGANA! You would think that at some point before direct translation of hirigana words into English, the game would present you with the challenge of trying to translate full words into their romanji phonetic pronunciations, a culmination of everything you have learned thus far. But it doesn't. It just expects users to direct translate hirigana into English after doing the barest minimum of showing you what the word means in English once... ten lessons ago. That is NOT how an educational game should logically and rationally build up to that skill. If the game's goal was to get you to that point, it needed to do more interactive exercises with words to get the learner TO that point. Again, the purpose of an educational game is to use THE GAMEPLAY to teach, not to present the information and then say, "Study it yourself." If someone wanted to study it themselves, they would have just studied it themselves, they wouldn't have bought A GAME to HELP them learn it.

So once again, in its endgame, the game fails to be more useful than any other educational resource available for learning Japanese, and can be argued to be actively detrimental.

STORY AND CHARACTERS
Skkkkkiiiiiiiippppp... Never before have I been so enamored with the "skip" button.

THE GAMEPLAY INTERFERES WITH LEARNING
Not only is this game an awful RPG, but the RPG aspects interfere with learning. You can lose a battle not because you gave a wrong answer, but because you haven't bothered leveling up your character's armor and weaponry or you didn't buy enough health packs or revives. It has nothing to do with learning, you just lose because you can't be bothered to give a crap about the RPG because it's soooooooo mediocre and sooooooo bare bones.

There's also a problem wherein the gameplay becomes so repetitive and boring you actively don't want to keep engaging with it. It's not exciting to learn a new language when you defeat "ri," "ro," and "ru" effortlessly for the twenty-seventh f****** time.

GLITCHES
It ran fine.

OVERALL
I give this game a 3/10, which is a shame, because there aren't a lot of educational resources like this on Steam. Unfortunately, I love the idea of this game more than I love the actual game. To its credit... it CAN teach you hirigana. To its detriment, it's not a good game, and the educational aspects could be a lot more effective. I really only recommend this for kids aged 6-9 and people who REALLY need some kind of guided activity to help them study. You're not getting anything more effective here than any other educational resource out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024965861', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1708382141}
review:
Works, kinda...?

I'm already studying 日本語 by other methods. In the first hour we only got to あいうえお, かきくけこ and がぎぐげご. The idea of making a game for learning is trying to ease the method of repetition.

That said, for a RPG Maker game using the RTP, it shows a lack of good map making. Some places are too big because they thought it would make sense. There could be ways to make the maps smaller or more attractive.

For the lessons, they`re ok, but one of the learning characters says that only with あいうえお they wouldn`t be able to form a word, and the teacher talks about consonants (?) in the next lesson. But いえ is a word made only of "vowels".  あい is another, if the game don't include Kanji. And so on.

Worth a buck in a sale, but don't expect much. Worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561199128406738', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1706892707}
review:
I guess it's alright for learning hiragana, and some vocabulary, but be careful with words that aren't actually used all that much like "watashi" or "anata" and things like that. It's best to learn vocabulary from people that actually speak Japanese. Even if you don't know hiragana, it'd be much, much quicker to learn it through something like the ToFuGu blog post, and much more memorable.

As a game it is very boring as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407052144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1705850844}
review:
I started this game already having learned hiragana, for practice. While I don't think it's as straightforward as it could have been, here are my views:

PROS:
- Interactive experience learning hiragana characters (RPG style)
- Constant battle encounters in which you have to practice your knowledge
- A cool story, to fight the final boss you need to get better at hiragana
- Most interactions with NPC are inspirational (motivating player to keep learning)
- Smalls details that make the game cuter (i.e. Ramune bottle that restores hp) 

CONS:
- The hiragana font could be simpler. It's a bit extra, making it hard to recognise strokes as a beginner
- The attack tab could be simplified (i.e. every k- character could have a subsection), because as you progress the game the list of answers becomes huge
- Some general UI issues (I can't choose the volume I want since it goes up by 20s, instead of conventional volume settings)

I would have liked an in-game drawing system to practice writing the characters as well, rather than on paper.

Overall this is a really cute, interactive game to practice hiragana. Very creative.

author: {'steamid': '76561199122343742', 'num_games_owned': 21, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1653207158}
review:
it teaches you some basic japenese letter/words and how their pronounces, what they look like etc and then when you fight those letters/words you have to know what they are, because if you dont your attacks do nothing unless you happened to choose the right answer. kind of like prodigy. then later it builds on what you just used, teaching more or combining if i had to guess (i didn't play much just kept messing around so ive only gotten new letters, 6 in total if my memory is right, got this game over a year ago)
you choose action and then select an enemy and then select what they are.
say you fight a 💀
and you choose 🤓.
it does no damage 💀💀💀
if you chose 💀 that enemies cooked and takes damage though.

haven't played a lot because idk i thought id die of laughter not learn japenese like some weeb. but you live in a village and some evil dude attacks the place with hiragana for whatever reason, then someone who knows japenese teaches you and your friends japenese so you can win against them. thats the first 10 or so mins of the game in a nutshell
still better than doulingo

bought it off some cdkey type of website a while ago for 50 cents or so thinking the name was a joke, but this game does teach japenese (as best a game could ig) 
if you really want to learn japenese, than maybe buying their other games would be smart choice, since your missing out on the other ones that teach important things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102381631', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1683560466}
review:
[quote]
[h2] "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" - Language Learning with a Playful Twist. [/h2]
[/quote]

[quote]
"Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" cleverly combines educational elements with a role-playing game format, creating a fun and engaging experience for those looking to learn the basics of the Japanese writing system.

The game's premise, where players embark on a quest to save a fictional world by mastering hiragana characters, adds a playful twist to language learning. The incorporation of RPG elements, such as battles and character progression, provides motivation and a sense of accomplishment.

The gradual introduction of hiragana characters, accompanied by pronunciation guides and examples, makes the learning process accessible and enjoyable. The inclusion of quizzes and challenges reinforces the newly acquired knowledge in an interactive way.

Visually, the game is appealing, with colorful graphics and character designs that enhance the overall experience. The soundtrack complements the game's lighthearted atmosphere.

"Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" successfully turns language learning into an entertaining adventure. Whether you're a beginner or looking to reinforce your hiragana skills, this game offers a unique and enjoyable approach to mastering the basics of the Japanese writing system.
[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561197999629349', 'num_games_owned': 2195, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1701896522}
review:
[h1]A Furry Gamer's In-Depth Review of "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle"[/h1]

[b]Reviewer:[/b] Kiba Snowpaw, a 36-year-old Furry male Ice Wolf from the ice world of HowlStrom, endowed with potent ice magic.

[b]Review:[/b] 

In the vast gaming universe, where adventures and learning intertwine like the intricate patterns of a spider's web, a game like "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" emerges as a beacon of ingenuity and educational fun. As Kiba Snowpaw, a seasoned gamer of the furry realm with a passion for both gaming and cultural exploration, I embarked on this unique journey with eagerness and anticipation.

[h2]Storyline and World-Building: An Icy HowlStrom Touch[/h2]

The game unfolds like a mystical scroll, revealing a world where the Japanese language is not just a means of communication but a key to unlocking hidden powers and secrets. The narrative, brimming with drama and action, resonates deeply with my icy heritage from HowlStrom. Each character, a symbol in Hiragana, transforms into a creature of lore, challenging my linguistic skills and strategic prowess.

[h3]Gameplay: A Battle of Wits and Words[/h3]

The battles, set in the backdrop of my frosty domain, demand more than just brute strength; they require the intellect of a seasoned language warrior. As I progressed, my ice magic intertwined with the newly acquired language skills, adding a furry flair to every encounter. The game's RPG elements, from item collection to quest completion, are seamlessly integrated, making the learning process both immersive and exhilarating.

[u]Educational Value: More Than Just a Game[/u]

As an Ice Wolf, my journey through this game was more than a conquest; it was a quest for knowledge. The detailed instructions on reading and writing each Hiragana character were akin to ancient scrolls, unraveling the mysteries of the Japanese language. The visual and audio aids were not merely tools but guides, like the northern stars guiding sailors in the icy seas of HowlStrom.

[strike]Challenges and Quizzes: The Ice Wolf's Test of Knowledge[/strike]

The in-game challenges and quizzes were no mere obstacles; they were trials set by the elders of HowlStrom, testing my grasp of this exotic language. Each victory was not just a triumph in battle but a step closer to mastering Hiragana, bringing honor to my furry lineage.

[h2]Conclusion: A Howling Success in Language Learning[/h2]

"Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle" is more than a game; it's a gateway to a new realm of understanding and cultural appreciation. It's a testament to the power of interactive learning, blending the thrill of an RPG with the satisfaction of acquiring a new language. As Kiba Snowpaw, an Ice Wolf with a voracious appetite for gaming and knowledge, I wholeheartedly endorse this adventure. It's a must-play for every furry gamer seeking to expand their horizons beyond the icy peaks of HowlStrom.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054183239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1706366304}
review:
Es un entretenido juego didáctico para aprender el hiragana y algún que otro vocabulario básico. Muy adecuado para principiantes de japonés. También sirve para repasar los conceptos más básicos del idioma para los que ya saben un poco.

Como juego, es un sencillo JRPG de estilo clásico con un diseño simpático y una agradable música que ayuda a estudiar lo que enseñan. Plantea una historia simple que ofrece la excusa perfecta (y algo original) de aprender japonés. Si quieres tomártelo en serio, ten a mano un cuaderno y lápiz para practicar la escritura.

Pillarlo de oferta, junto con los otros dos juegos de la serie (katakana battle y kenji battle) es altamente recomendable. Por menos de 4 € te llevas un lote de juegos didácticos, que si te los tomas en serios, conseguirás tener una pequeña base de japonés a la vez que te diviertes.

------------
ENGLISH
------------
It is an entertaining educational game to learn hiragana and some other basic vocabulary. Very suitable for Japanese beginners. It also serves to review the most basic concepts of the language for those who already know a little.

As a game, it is a simple classic-style JRPG with a nice design and pleasant music that helps you study what they teach. It presents a simple story that offers the perfect (and somewhat original) excuse to learn Japanese. If you want to take it seriously, have a notebook and pencil handy to practice writing.

Getting it on sale, along with the other two games in the series (katakana battle and kenji battle) is highly recommended. For less than €4 you get a set of educational games, which if you take them seriously, you will be able to have a small base of Japanese while having fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992438116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 497, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1702123718}
review: Learn Japanese to survive - Hiragana Battle est un jeu éducatif qui permet d'apprendre les Hiragana japonais en suivant les aventures d'un groupe de 4 héros. Le jeu se présente sous la forme d'un RPG en 2D avec des combats au tour par tour. Ici les ennemis sont remplacés par des caractères Hiragana et il faut donner leur traduction en guise d'attaque afin de combattre. Si le début est facile avec seulement quelques caractères à connaître, les choses se corsent au fil du jeu et pour le final ce sont de mots de vocabulaire qu'il faut trouver. Du coup si vous avez bien appris les mots tout ira bien et sinon les derniers combats vont devenir un cauchemar. Du coup le jeu est à réserver à celles et ceux qui vont utiliser ce jeu pour ce qu'il est, un jeu éducatif.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074682258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1700430256}
review:
Meh.

Wanted to brush up on my hiragana in a fun way. But the lack of ability to skip cut scenes, or speed through dialog makes this largely a waste of time. Gave up after only the first few battles.

You already know how to write half the hiragana? Enjoy watching a video of them being *slowly* drawn. Make sure you don't accidentally click to repeat the video because you are spamming the enter-key to go to the next dialog. Enjoy watching the same unstoppable video again.

Even for people completely new to Japanese, I think there must be better games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561199163369506', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1697219459}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle is a game developed by Sleepy Duck and released in March 2016 1. The game is an educational RPG that teaches players how to read and write Japanese characters (Hiragana) in a fun and engaging way 1. The game is set up like a classic 16-bit RPG, where you play as the protagonist who is learning Japanese from a teacher. The game has three chapters, and each chapter introduces a new set of characters to learn 1.

The game has several pros. It teaches Hiragana in bite-sized pieces, making it easy to learn and memorize. The game also has vocab lessons and basic grammar lessons that are helpful for beginners 1. The game’s use of repetition to help players remember Hiragana is also commendable 1. The game’s price point is also affordable, making it accessible to many people 1.

However, there are some downsides to the game. The music can be repetitive, and the storyline is not very interesting 2. The characters are not well-developed, which can make it difficult for players to become invested in them or the game 2. The game’s use of calligraphy-style Hiragana can also be confusing at times, as it doesn’t always match the font used in battle 2.

Overall, Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle is a great game for early or casual Japanese learners. It has its flaws but is still worth playing if you’re interested in learning Hiragana.

Some other people have reviewed:

https://www.reddit.com/r/LearnJapanese/comments/m14wln/review_of_learn_japanese_to_survive_hiragana/

author: {'steamid': '76561197980593659', 'num_games_owned': 1493, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1694395404}
review:
A few zones in to this game I was ready to recommend it, but it falls apart down the line.

First to get the game part out of the way: it's a terrible video game. The plot is bad, the mechanics are bad, the interface is a hassle, and the type of game it is ultimately subtracts from its real goal.

As a tool to learn hiragana: I would not recommend using this as your sole or even main method. Because of the way the RPG enemies are each a hiragana, and therefore spawn in one location with one set of tasks, the game becomes a series of areas where you will be dealing with an extremely small subset of hiragana at a time. By the time you're learning ha/ho/fu/hi/he, you will never again see ka/ko/ku/ki/ke. You will also never have to draw the shapes. You will learn a small, seemingly random handful of words and grammar tips. There's a very strange escalation at the end of the game that feels like a surprise pop quiz on words, but otherwise you'll be fighting groups of 5-15 of the same enemy at any given time.

With all of that in mind, if you are using 1-2 other things to also learn hiragana and just want like a weird little experience that will ask you to remember some hiragana, this is fine. I'll probably still try the katakana one. I wanted it to be over about halfway through. My playtime is super overinflated by leaving the game running in the background while doing other things so I can't speak to the actual length, but it overstays its welcome. I thought that would be a strength, with JRPG grinding being the perfect excuse to spam hiragana practice, but because it's the same enemies in a given area, you sometimes just load the same fight you just fought and don't even have to think about what you're doing, because the characters still have the last thing you did selected.

author: {'steamid': '76561199407517110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1692369722}
review:
I love this game. Is such a good idea. I've dabbled with Japanese years ago, so this has helped me pick up things pretty quick. Re-learnt 35 symbols in 3 days. 

There are a couple of suggestions i have that would make this perfect though. I dont expect any to be implemented but id be remiss if i didnt mention them. 

1- I'd like the characters to move faster, particularly during a cut scenes, the characters move a little painfully slow. But also moving around in general. 

2- (The biggest issue i have) I'm not a fan of having to chose all the characters moves at once. Sometimes an enemy has perished (making a pre-chosen move a waste)  or a character has been injured and i need to instead heal or attack a different character than planned but cant. 
Or the main thing is having one enemy left with one hit left before being defeated. but you have to select a move for all 4 characters. This wastes a bit of time per battle that quickly starts to add up a fair bit when playing. Reducing the enjoyment of gameplay. 

I'd love it to let you choose an attack with each individual character when its their turn (like most turn based games) This would save a lot of time allowing me to fight more enemies in the same amount of time and therefore practice learning more. 

Great game though, i highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561199146765688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1692987570}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105590811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1695332998}
review:
It would have been a great educational game if combat wasn't so punishing.
It doesn't matter if you know hiragana and answer [u]correctly[/u] [b]ALL THE TIME[/b], your party is still going to receive huge amounts of damage, more so if enemies get to go first (surpise attack as it's called here).
On top of that, combat encounters are so frequent that I have no choice but to flee from all of them that can be fled from.
However, thanks to surprise attack mechanic, sometimes my party gets damaged nonetheless, making it very difficult to simply traverse places.
Be ready to spend a lot of yen on revives and healing potions. Or do not play altogether.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064661697', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1688655590}
review:
Let me first start of by saying the idea is fantastic, and it worked really good in the beginning. The story is a bit silly, but not too bad. I wish there were a bit more variety on the "classes", like a mage would be nice, but that doesn't matter too much.

So, why a negative review? 
Beacuse while the idea is BRILLIANT, and works great in the start, at least for me, it quite quickly fell apart.
The combat works like this, the game plays like your basic RPGMaker game, however instead of normal enemies, you fight Hiragana, and the only way to damage them is by using "Attacks" that are their Romaji counterparts. So to attack "が" you would have to use "Ga", and so on. 
While this is a genius way to learn it, there is one VERY big problem with the execution...

Every single Hiragana, and Dakuon variant, have their own seperate Attack. 

This combined with that you have serveral characters, all of which you have to select the Attack with, means you'll be scrolling through Attacks more than you'll actually end up thinking and "learning", as your "Attack" list will be literally over 40 Attacks long. 

A few ways this could be solved would be...

1. You usually face a select number of different Hiragana per map, so one way would be if you simply only had access to the Romaji "Attacks" that would be relevant on that map. 

2. Again, since theres usually a select number of different Hiragana per map, some of the "Attacks" could contain 2-4 different Romaji, and then simply make sure most maps only contained a limited number of ones under the same attack. While this would still leave quite a few attacks, it would be easier to make than option 1 in regards to RPGMaker, and it would still cut the number of attacks and scrolling time in half, or more, which would be enough to make it feel worth the scrolling time.

If Option 2 would be too messy, to make sure everyone knew which Romaji it actually was, a way to make this easier would be to make the Hiragana's "Take damage" sprite show their Romaji, since you would only see if it you already hit it with the correct Attack. anyways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198917072413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1689455480}

author: {'steamid': '76561198153276979', 'num_games_owned': 693, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1695393215}
review:
Ну, как старт для изучения японского - наверное может подойти, но как игра... meh.

Достаточно дешевенькая JRPG, где вместо выбора способностей ты должен выбирать то, какой перед тобой иероглиф. Перед этим тебе достаточно подробно и понятно все объяснят и наглядно продемонстрируют. Визуал ни о чем, звук пососный, сюжет не цепляет, персонажи будто стоковые какие-то. По сути перед вами просто геймификация изучения японского (что, как мне кажется, вообще не требуется, японский сам по себе очень интересно учить)

Не рекомендую играть в эту игру, но очень рекомендую попробовать начать учить японский язык, для чего, наверное, эта игра может дать заряд мотивации и какую-никакую базу. А как только она надоест - смело забывайте и переходите на Duolingo или Memrise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008934797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1688362475}
review:
I purchased the entire series when it was in humble bundle. I learned hiragana, katakana and some kani when I was in school decades ago and wanted to test to see how much I could remember from back then. I started with hiragana because that was what I could remember the best. 

I would say that the game is good for practising but not great at teaching the symbols very well. When I learned in school there were a lot of learning devices employed that made it easier to remember each symbol (for example: "me" is eye in japanese and the hiragana symbol for me looks like an eye, the symbol for a looks like an eye with a sword going through it so you remember it like "ah! there's something in my eye"). I'm not sure how well I would have done had I not remembered all of those hints I learned as a kid. With that being said, if you have already learned the symbols, this game is really good for testing yourself instead of using flashcards.

author: {'steamid': '76561199239855155', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1690115363}
review:
hiragana oyun olmadan da öğrenebileceğiniz en basit ve en temel alfabe. oyun size bunu sevimli bir "savaş" formatında keyifle ve *tekrarlatarak* öğrenmeyi vadediyor, eğer seviyorsanız alabilirsiniz. benim önerilerim oyundan ziyade dili gerçekten öğrenmek isteyenlere yönelik olacak.
latin alfabesinden daha farklı olmasından dolayı en başlarda epey yabancı kalmak çok doğal ancak bunu engellemenin en temel yolu kelimeleri sürekli yazarak el alışkanlığı geliştirmek. oyunu bitirip kenara koyarsanız alfabeyi unutmanız [b]1 haftadan kısa[/b] sürer.

*ki (き) gibi bazı karakterlerde altta dışa doğru bir oval çizerek ilerleyen kısımda kesik olduğunu göreceksiniz. oyun sizi el yazısı formatına alıştırmak için bunu göstermeyi tercih etmiş. dijital ya da basılı metinlerde kesik olmadan, "き" şeklinde yazılır; el yazısıyla yazılmış mektup veya yazılardaysa orada genellikle bir kesik mevcuttur. yani, farklı iki format kafanızı karıştırmasın ikisi de doğru.
*japoncanın 40.000 tane kanji içermesi göz korkutuyor ancak 3200 adet kanji bilmek gündelik bir gazeteyi okumak için yeterli
*hiragana da dahil alfabelerde gösterilen vowellerin nereden başlanılarak çizildiğine dikkat edin, çizim sırasına göre ilerlemek kolaylık sağlıyor (か yazımında ilk adım sola doğru eğik olan o çizgiyi çekmek değildir)
*japonca öğrenirken kaynak olarak bir kitap kullanacaksanız, her bilginin doğru olduğunu varsaymayın ve her bilgiyi olduğu gibi kullanmayın; çünkü bazı ifadeler epey eski ve günlük hayatta neredeyse hiç konuşulmuyor (yaşça büyük kişilere あなた hitabı fazla laubali kaçar)
*hiragana-katakana-kanji sırasından şaşmayın (romaji bir öğrenme yöntemi değil)
*animelerde duyulan ses tonları ve telaffuz şekli gündelik hayata hiç benzemiyor, oradaki telaffuzları örnek almayın
*dil bilgisi de bilseniz kelime + kanji eksiğiniz olduğu sürece asla tam hissetmeyeceksiniz, o yüzden yavaş ama kelimeleri gerçekten öğrenerek ilerlerseniz hem okumanız hızlanır hem de yazarken daha hızlı yazmaya başlarsınız
*bazı podcastlerde gerçekten çok seri konuştukları için birçok şeyi kaçırıp anlamıyormuş gibi hissetmek moral bozabiliyor, podcastlerden yararlanacaksanız ilk başlarda yavaşlatarak dinleyebilirsiniz. başlangıç için spotify'da epey podcast var, aceleye getirmeyip onlarla başlayabilirsiniz.
*kelimelerin hiragana formatını öğrenip kolaya kaçmayın, kanji bilmek çok önemli gerekirse çalışmalarınızın büyük bir bölümünü bunun için ayırın


[b][i]en önemlisi[/i][/b]: japoncayı öğrenmek çok uzun bir çaba ve emek istiyor, moral bozmamak gerektiği gibi üstünkörü öğrenmemek de gerekiyor. konuşmayı öğrenmek kolay, zor olan yazabilmek ve okuyabilmek; bu yüzden diğer dillerin aksine yazı pratiği ve okuma pratiğine konuşma pratiğinden daha fazla vakit ayırmak gerekiyor
alışmak için worksheetleri kullanabilirsiniz, internette birçok formatı mevcut // bkz: https://www.mlcjapanese.co.jp/Download/HiraganaKatakanaWorksheet.pdf

author: {'steamid': '76561198380756202', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1231, 'last_played': 1695235693}
review:
[h1] Aprendendo hiragana na base do Grinding [/h1]

Basicamente RPG por turno + aprender japonês... Oque é GENIAL, a melhor forma de aprender e memorizar algo é na base da repetição, e oque é melhor do que um RPG para utilizar a repetição e ser divertido ao mesmo tempo? A historia do jogo é simples mas divertida de ver: Um mago chamado Noburo tem o poder de criar guerreiros chamados "Guerreiros Hiragana" (Não preciso explicar que Hiragana é o primeiro alphabeto do japonês né?) que são indestrutiveis... Bem... Exceto se você souber o som que essas letras fazem. Após o mago destruir a vila da protagonista ela fica determinada a aprender japonês para impedir que Noburo cause mais destruição, nessa jornada tem uns mini plot twists aqui e ali então é... Para um jogo educacional a história é até que boa.

[h1] Perfeito para aprender do zero [/h1]

Se você mora em uma caverna e nunca teve contato com japonês na vida... [spoiler][strike] Recomendo você investir em uma casa [/strike][/spoiler] Esse jogo é perfeito para você... bem... se você souber inglês primeiro... Maaaaas ainda sim é um bom ponto de partida para se divertir e realmente decorar cada um das 46 letras japonesas do primeiro alfabeto. O jogo também ensina palavras e um pouco de gramatica no final do jogo, mas o real foco dele é introduzir ao idioma, ou seja, não espere sair falando japonês e assistir anime sem legenda logo depois de zerar... Mas você já vai conseguir ler algumas coisas uma vez que sabe o som que cada letra faz. Ainda há outros dois jogos na franquia que mostram os dois outros alfabetos e todos eles são necessários para o completo entendimento do idioma, mas decorar o primeiro alfabeto já é um grande passo para aprender japonês.

[h1] Em resumo... [/h1]

Jogo MUITO BOM para quem quer começar aprender, com uma historia exageradamente dramática para um jogo educativo que tanto testa suas habilidades de estratégia quanto suas habilidades de memoria e japonês. O jogo é realmente divertido então se você curte um bom e clássico RPG e quer aprender Japonês recomendo demais esse jogo.

NOTA: Japonês/10 :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198133957558', 'num_games_owned': 757, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1708805137}

author: {'steamid': '76561198258155985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1684181624}
review:
You'll learn how to read and write [u]all the hiragana characters[/u], some [u]simple vocabulary[/u] and a [u]tiny bit of grammar[/u].

I came here with 0% knowledge of japanese and this game was a good way to start. Since it's a game it was actually fun and very helpful to stay motivated. You can [i]save your progress at any time[/i] and revise lessons you have already learned.

Recommendations from my own experience: [list]
[*]Make notes (using different colours makes it sometimes easier)
[*]Practice writing a lot (I still need to practice more; reading works fine for me at this point but I still struggle with writing)
[*]Take enough breaks so you don't feel overwhelmed
[*]Don't rush from lesson to lesson
[*]Complete the side-quests, they are pretty helpful [/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198054084699', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1700985152}
review: Amazing. Been trying to learn nihongo for a almost a year now and i'm finally getting into the writing bit and the books bored me and i felt i was forgetting everything i learned after just taking a break but this game actually keeps me entertained and the pace is perfect. Also bought the study book, gonna print that out here pretty soon, just wish the flash cards were available on steam as well. Highly recommend but you defiantly need to keep notes and practice the words at least 3 times a week and if your not motivated, find motivation otherwise don't bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069675932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1682976626}
review:
This is a pretty good game for me to refamiliarise myself with hiragana, but it would be a lot harder if I wasn't already familiar with the writing system from half a semester of Japanese class.  This game focuses on hiragana but includes some vocabulary, mostly in the side quests.

My only quibbles are minor. I wish there were optional mini-games in order to practice vocabulary, and it would be nice if there were some for hiragana as well. I'm playing a game because I don't want to bother with physical objects so the lack of practice baked into the game means I'm not really learning the vocabulary presented. I also wish the vocabulary were presented written out in hiragana and in romaji, but not with the mixed hiragana-learned-so-far and romaji-for-hiragana-not-yet-learned. As someone with some familiarity that's just confusing. 

Still, the game is meant to teach hiragana, and that's what it does.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067164076', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1682465219}
review:
I wanted to like this more than I ended up in the end. I'm still going to hit recommend because it could be helpful to certain people but it is not suitable for a main way to learn hiragana IMO.

I used mainly duolingo and realkana.com to learn the hiragana characters while Hiragana Battle was a slower way to review them (which is sometimes a benefit). I would recommend trying those resources first before purchasing this game. real kana lets you select which kana you would like to review and if you know the kana you can go quite quickly with it. My initial impression of this game was much more positive when I started compared to later.

Pros:
-Works perfectly on the Steam deck - So could be great for offline on the go learning. If this is important to you, I would say it's worth playing probably.
-Kindof goofy charm in the story/characters
-Pretty good music that isn't too distracting
-decent art & graphics
- If you like turnbased JRPGs, the combat can be a bit fun. 

Cons:
-Introduces some things way too early. It teaches dakuten and hadakuten (characters that have slight differences that change their sound, like は vs ば) alongside the base characters, where I feel they are best learned later on and even help review the main characters that way. It also tries to teach you vocab alongside characters where really you should probably focus on your kana first. It even teaches you words it hasn't taught you all the characters for yet and at one point says something a bit misleading (which it explains the next lesson, but still.)
-The TTS voices aren't amazing (they get the job done though)

So all in all, I would recommend trying free resources first but if you find they aren't working for you personally, maybe this is worth a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271961189', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1685047934}
review:
This game is definitely fun. Great as supplementary material even though the pace can be a bit slow, and I prerfer to not learn romanji without the Hiragana. So far there are sections that teach only romanji or does this weird half Hiragana half romanji style stuff. For the price and the effort it is great fun and I recommend it. Someone else mentioned they would like to see these dev take another crack at Hiragana and I am inclined to agree. 

Speaking of the game it is a standard turn based rpg. Kept simple and fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198402713743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1680739267}

author: {'steamid': '76561198201246082', 'num_games_owned': 3232, 'num_reviews': 1500, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1656178374}
review:
Hayatta Kalmak İçin Japonca Öğrenin! Hiragana Battle, Sleepy Duck tarafından geliştirilen ve RIVER CROW STUDIO tarafından yayınlanan bir eğitim oyunudur. Oyunculara Hiragana yazı sistemini tanıtarak Japon dilinin temellerini öğretmek için tasarlanmıştır. Oyun, ilgi çekici bir hikaye, heyecan verici savaşlar ve görevler ve eşya toplama gibi tanıdık RPG unsurları ile tam gelişmiş bir RPG olarak sunulmaktadır.

Oyuncular görsel animasyonlar ve sesli konuşma örnekleriyle her bir Hiragana karakterinin nasıl okunacağını ve yazılacağını öğrenirler. Oyunda öğrendiklerinizi test etmek için sınavlar vardır ve bilgilerinizi tazelemek için tamamladığınız dersleri gözden geçirebilirsiniz. Oyun aynı zamanda yaygın Japonca sözcük ve deyimleri ve önemli dilbilgisi noktalarını da öğretir.

Hikaye, canavarları yenmek ve dünyayı kurtarmak için Hiragana öğrenmek zorunda oldukları bir fantezi dünyasına taşınan bir grup öğrenciyi takip ediyor. Oyunda ilerledikçe yeni Hiragana karakterleri öğrenecek ve bilgilerinizi kullanarak stratejik savaşlara katılacaksınız. Oyun sizi meşgul edecek, zorlayacak ve daha fazlası için geri gelmenizi sağlayacak şekilde tasarlanmıştır.

Genel olarak, Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Savaşı Japonca diline harika bir giriş kursu. İyi tasarlanmış, ilgi çekici ve oynaması eğlenceli. İster yeni başlayın ister Japonca bilginiz olsun, bu oyun dil becerilerinizi geliştirmek için mükemmel bir yoldur.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060936212', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1680072224}
review:
6/10

Наверное, эта рецензия не будет совсем уж объективной, так как я уже сносно читал хирагану до запуска игры, поэтому мало чему научился. И сами битвы были преимущественно легкими по той же причине. Но мнение все же составил.

Удивительное.
У японских ролевых игр (JRPG) помимо своеобразного визуального стиля есть еще определенные законы игры. И один из них - гринд ради прокачки. Что удивительно и забавно, в плане обучения повторение наоборот является одним из краеугольных камней, так что можно смело говорить, кто конкретно в этой игре гринд оправдан. Что, однако, не избавляет игру от других неприятных особенностей, из-за которых я стараюсь обходить JRPG за километр. Например, нудной возни с параметрами и инвентарем, консольного подхода к управлению и условностей изображения битв. Последнее не так режет глаз здесь, так как сама идея сражения с абстрактными символами - уже условность. Другой интересный момент: даже зная хирагану идеально, вы можете проиграть из-за непродуманного подхода к прокачке и ресурсам. Потому что знание этой слоговой азбуки позволяет просто наносить урон, и дальше перед нами уже классическая JRPG битва. Исправляются авторы буквально на последней битве с главным боссом - там решают все исключительно знания языка, но и права на ошибку нет.

Плюсы.
- С основной своей задачей - зубрежкой хираганы - игра вполне справляется. Но я бы не сказал, что она подходит к этому творчески и задействует что-то помимо гринда.
- Из приятного - символы не только читаются как текст, но еще и озвучиваются, приводится начертание. Можно тренировать владение хираганой комплексно. Но в боях решает только текст, думаю, в силу ограничений самого движка. Порисовать мышкой и помычать в микрофон не дают.
- Основная часть игры - заучивание самой азбуки, но в конце дают немного разгуляться и со словами. Это воспринимается интереснее, но контента мало.

Минусы.
- В игре мало прав на ошибку. Ходы всей партии задаются наперед, а противнику обычно требуется больше одного удара, поэтому ошибка в интерпретации символа или слова приводит к пачке потерянных атак вместо одной. А если противника удается завалить меньшим числом ударов, оставшиеся в запасе ни к чему не приведут, так как не на "свои" символы они просто не действуют.
- Не дается никаких особых техник запоминания вроде ассоциативной памяти. А для меня это был ключевой инструмент в запоминании азбук. Без него все было бы гораздо сложнее.
- Монстры всегда нападают фиксированными партиями, из-за чего часто вас ждут однотипные сражения, а некоторые символы избегают зубрежки. При этом враги этими партиями появляются будто случайно. Я бы наверное привязал конкретных противников к узким местам согласно методическим рекомендациям.
- По той же причине игра почему-то не тренирует сложные случаи. Например, было бы классно сразиться с пачкой таких врагов сразу: われね. Или таких: ちきさ. Или даже таких: はまよほ. На повторных тестах я косячу именно в этих местах обычно.
- Символы дают и сразу проверяют в боях. А вот со словами не так. Их дают в течение всей игры и особо не контролируют запоминание. Но вдруг в финальных боях без этих знаний никуда. Так что да - я читерил в половине случаев.

В общем, как JRPG игра явно слабенькая и короткая (и на том спасибо). Как обучающий инструмент, она скорее подходит для повторения или сопутствующего изучения, нежели как основной источник знаний. Но сплав игровых и образовательных механик по крайней мере удался.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988449961', 'num_games_owned': 762, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1680107589}
review: I've always seemed to have trouble learning and retaining the Japanese I've attempted over the years.  My attention span has always been an issue.  Since starting this game, it seems like I've been able to retain more and faster than I used to.  I believe it has something to do with how similar it is to playing Final Fantasy games of my youth, as FF6 was my absolute favorite.  For an RPGMaker game, I've found it enjoyable and fun to play while definitely learning.  I hope this progress continues and that I can progress to the Katakana and Kanji versions of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126291459', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1577, 'last_played': 1678726110}
review:
Fun way to learn Hiragana in few days.
If you think gojuon charts is difficult to read, this game will help you to memorize.

Kana Signs: Take Note How Much You Read and Write every Night.
Aあ Kaか Saさ Taた Naな Haは Maま Yaや Raら Waわ Nん

author: {'steamid': '76561199227674495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1679599648}
review: Fun way to learn Japanese.  It took me a while to understand how to attack opponents.  As a game it is too easy but it creates repetition to practice recognizing the symbols.  I recommend this game to learn Japanese symbols.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044884974', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1678764041}
review:
I played through this game alongside textbook-based self-learning. Memorization and study requires repetition and I found this to be a useful tool in entertaining me and keeping my attention while drilling hiragana into my head. I have a lot more confidence in recognizing hiragana at a glance now. Overall the game did exactly what I wanted it to, and I got it on a great sale. It's an education tool, and I found it an effective one for a reasonable price. 

Perhaps my biggest critique is that the battle "groups" are not randomized as much as I wish they were. The same sets appeared in the same order several times in a row, especially with the ya, yu, yo and wa, wo, n sets. I was fighting the same battles with the same commands queued up too many times. I would have liked to see more randomization in how the hiragana spawned into fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198812859050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1688320889}
review: I have great appreciation for this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198097588765', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1678640949}
review:
Don't get me wrong, I think this game is good for learning/reviewing hiragana and vocabulary. I really wish I could keep playing it, I'm a big supporter of gamification when it comes to teaching languges and I believe the game is great for that.
BUT.
It isn't so good when it comes to game design. I think I have reached the 5th lesson and the attack screen is extremely overwhelming, I don't want to imagine how it will be at the end of the game. On top of that, you get a random battle what feels like every five seconds and you have to grind in order to not be destroyed by the enemies. The game even offers to level you up with points obtained with side quests, but you barely get side quests, so doesn't make much sense.

If the fights were less frequent/easier and there was a way to make the attack selection faster (typing my answer instead of choosing from a list) I would definitely complete the game, but as it stands right now it takes too much time and attention per battle even for a person who already knows hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084561752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1677593455}
review:
I won't indulge too long on the main issue with this game which is the redundancy of the fights, you can simply escape them once you feel you have trained enough. 

What I liked the most (and that differentiates it from other gaming learning platforms such as Duolingo), it's the focus on the writing. 
I combined this class with the Duolingo app and I felt it was a good combination for improving reading, listening, writing and speaking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012813175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1620589887}
review: It´s a really good game for beginners how to read and write Japanese Hiragana. The lessons build on each other very well and everything is explained well. The story is also very nicely implemented and connected to the lessons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057344186', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1677345952}
review:
Game is a neat little introduction to Japanese. Learn some basic vocabulary and phrases (~100), as well as a little bit about Japan and of course the Hiragana characters.

That said, the game has its caveats...
The game is an RPGmaker game, although it really doesn`t need to be. The RPG elements add nothing to the game.
Hiragana characters are introduced far too slowly and "fights" tend to be repetitive throughout the game.

If you have no knowledge of the Japanese language, this game is a nice starting point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138725696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1677953083}
review:
Tolles Spiel. Man lernt echt sehr intensiv Hiragana. Ich finde auch toll, dass man nebenbei noch viele Wörter und Redewendungen mitbekommt. Es lohnt sich, vor Beginn des Spiels ein Vokabelheft und Schmierpapier zum schreiben üben anzuschaffen. Das Spiel sagt es immer nur so nebenbei, aber es lohnt sich, die Zeit zu nehmen und alles immer wieder mal niederzuschreiben.
Zum Spiel an sich lässt sich nicht viel sagen. Ohne den Lernzweck würde ich es wohl nicht spielen. Allerdings finde ich das lernen mit dem Spiel deutlich angenehmer ist, als sich stumpf hinzuhocken und die Zeichen zu lernen. Zudem gibt es einen guten Leitfaden vor und das kleine Belohnungssystem ist nochmal extra ein Sahnehäubchen.

author: {'steamid': '76561199183948405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1688204526}
review: Oyun Hiragana alfabesini öğrenmek istiyenler için uygundur ve aynı zamanda eğlenceliydi...Savaş mantığı temel sıra tabanlı oyunlarla aynı karakterleri seviye atlatınca skiller açıp dahada taktiksel oynanabilir.Ayrıca bazı temel kelimeleride öğretiyor.Hikayesi pek iyi değil ama zaten bu oyunu hikayesi için almanıza gerek yok.Ama kesinlikle almanızı öneririm.

author: {'steamid': '76561199243633614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1676697316}
review:
Two things: 
1. It isn't usable with a controller 
2. If you don't have a pen/pencil and a notebook to practice drawing the characters, then I feel you are wasting your money.

This is a good game to play on a computer that has room to write on. Make sure your desk is big enough so that you aren't writing in your lap. 

CONS: I wish it didn't speed through the text if I accidentally press a key too long. I missed some of the conversations and storyline because of this.

I enjoyed it. For the trilogy pack being only $6, I'm going to recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198971309045', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1676438214}
review: 想起了小时候玩过的教学碟片

author: {'steamid': '76561198326097650', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1676122858}
review:
Awesome game.

First, it is accessible to anyone, the game will never ask you do to something it didn't teach you.
Second, it is very progressive, you won't be overwhelmed by a bunch of pointless informations
The combat system is simplistic but does the job well enough. Repetitive yes but repetition is a good way to learn new things

The pixelarts and musics are nice, doesn't feel like a cheap game. The story is generic but who cares.

Note that it won't only teach you Hiragana but also quite a few vocabulary words and some very very basic grammar and sentences.

Obviously, you'd learn much faster studying in a regular way. But if you just want/need to start your japanese journey somewhere, it's a good beginning. It will teach you slowly, but you'll probably spend more time on average playing a fun game than you'd studying elsewhere

author: {'steamid': '76561199107029970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1673746702}
review: Начнём с того что игра сама по себе ИЗНАЧАЛЬНО) выглядит круто: джеерпеге в котором ты учишь язык, тутгеймификация поможет тебе получать удовольствие от обучения и скорее всего ты пройдёшь игру и запомнишь азбуку НО какого-то хуя разрабы решили ебануть мобов которые хуячат направо и налево твоих персов с двух тычек, а учитывая кривую экономику где за 1к голды ты можешь купить 1 ревайв это супер не балансно, а ревайвы заканчиваются быстро, помимо этого эти ебучие мобы ещё и бьют первыми, перед твоими персонажами что может тупо поломать весь файт если буквы решат по приколу фокуснуть 1го героя, а ну и конечно бывают такие ситуации где ты даже не можешь сразу от них съебать а они просто берут и начинают тебя пинать из засады, ну, хорошо что это начинается с середины азбуки, единственный выход просто скипать файты по кд пока ты не дойдёшь до файнал босса, потому что у тебя тупо не хватит ресурсов, а что если я скажу что некоторые файты ещё и нельзя скипать, так как по итогу учить азбуку? нужно смотреть на буквы в файте, потом проверять правильно ли ты ответил где-то в браузере смотря на азбуку и просто давать по съёбам, браво, интересно потестить катакану и кандзи, игру я так и не прошёл потому что тупо выучил азбуку просто без НЕЁ по онлайн ФЛЕШ игрухе + видосу Learn all Hiragana in 1hour что и вам парни советую сделать, не буду говорить что сама игра ещё пиздец затянута, я хз зачем это было сделано видимо разрабы вдохновлялись при создании дарк соулсом

author: {'steamid': '76561199238977713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1685095634}
review:
Bought and downloaded cuz I think the combat mechanics are challenging and educational. Apart from sprint turned off the main issue I had was lack of info on what the Hirigana character opponents do against you.

* Lack of basic stats on the enemy. Theres no encyclopedia of sorts in the game that records enemy stats before and after you defeat them.
* You dont know what skillsets the Hirigana opponent has and how much damage it does.
* Their targeting method seems to be random.
* The pattern on who gets to strike seems to be on who has the best stats in the fight?

Id appreciate the game more if the number of burst damage opponents are reduced and replaced with more skills that slowly drain your life per turn because whenever the player reaches a new level of the game they would face stronger opponents, and since the enemy's stats are definitely always higher they would always make the first blows resulting in heavy casualties despite the player getting all the answers correct. This results in repeatedly retreating all the way back to home base for replenishments until the your team slowly levels up to withstand atleast 5 fights or more before the area boss fight.

It was not challenging as I thought when it comes to damage numbers but all in all, you can learn fast because its a life or death scenario. Despite it all I had fun. Recommended for people who want a challenging memory game that isnt for babies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025071404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1496258307}

author: {'steamid': '76561198183406253', 'num_games_owned': 771, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1673533218}
review:
I haven't had the chance to learn Hiragana with this game, but instead practice Hiragana with, because I already learned how to read and write Hiragana with a traditional method. But I could say that this game should help with learning as well, as long as you're taking notes and practicing how to write. Besides Hiragana characters, the game also teaches about several everyday vocabulary, simple grammar lessons and some phrases that's being commonly used. My only nitpick is that it's an RPGMaker game, other than that it's a pretty solid resorce for educational gaming.

Rating: B

author: {'steamid': '76561197986297793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1673306685}
review:
La promesse d'une aide à l'apprentissage du japonais en s'amusant était belle et ayant déjà étudié la langue par le passé, je me suis laissé tenté par une révision rapide des fondamentaux... Mais j'ai été fort déçu.

Tout d'abord, il faut le savoir, il s'agit d'un jeu réalisé sous RPG Maker. De manière peu étonnante, les mécaniques sont limitées et peu adaptées à l'apprentissage.

Mon constat sur 1h de jeu: des combats randoms, répétitifs et inintéressants, une sévère lenteur d'apprentissage, l'obligation d'utiliser feuille et crayon pour dessiner les syllabes (alors que les applications mobiles disposent parfois d'un outil pour tracer les symboles à l'écran), l'absence d'apprentissage de vocabulaire de base en parallèle du syllabaire... 

Personnellement, ce jeu m'a rappelé à quel point le japonais doit s'apprendre avec discipline et travail appliqué. On ne peut pas faire les choses à moitié. 

Quitte à utiliser une application, je recommande plutôt celles qu'on trouve sur mobile, qui permettent à la fois de tracer, lire, écouter, varier les activités, obtenir des conseils et disposer d'un minimum de culture (JA Sensei par exemple).

author: {'steamid': '76561199043455479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1391, 'last_played': 1673202718}
review: This is the hardest out of the three games(hiragana,katakana,kanji) weapons and equipment matter. Pay attention to those random vocabulary too. Also expect to fight someone every 5 steps. So it's great for remembering the hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030170536', 'num_games_owned': 1875, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1673197198}
review: Very slow. Not exciting. No 'skip' possibilities as far as I could see.

author: {'steamid': '76561198359659323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1673324620}
review:
bear in mind I'm an intermediate learner, so everything in this game I've had known for quite some time so I can't really comment on the educational aspect, but this feels like a very good resource! plus I had fun with it
it's a little clunky, enemy encounter rate can get pretty annoying, and going through the answers is a little slow late-game, but those can be chalked up to side-effects of being the first in a game series
it strikes a pretty good balance being educational and a game, and things change from time to time so it doesn't get too stale. something I appreciate is how the background always change to reflect exactly where you are even in battle, it makes battling feel more natural even though you're always getting jumped out of nowhere. there's also a lot of fun moments with your party mates and npcs, I really liked finding english learners in some areas
I like how things change late-game, and I really enjoyed the final boss
if you wanna learn hiragana and some vocabulary through this game I say go for it, with the constant battles the hiragana will probably be ingrained into your brain by the end of it, but you can always escape battles and save anywhere if you need a break (never skipping battles makes you quite hardy for the end of the game is what I found out though)
it may sound a little daunting, but it's a short game and you'll always have the story and your own learning journey driving you to the end :)
I look forward to playing the other games in this trilogy

author: {'steamid': '76561198321870839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1672898235}
review:
This is indeed a game.

It has watered down mechanics from the original Final Fantasy, with the attacks being determined by your ability to recognize the hiragana characters. It's simple and effective, albeit a bit tiring after a while. It is a bit primitive (also similar to FF1) especially for a 2016 game, but really that didn't bother me at all. 

This game has the best writing I've ever seen in a Japanese language learning game. It's a genius work of ironic drama, where you cringe so hard that you can't help but laugh. This is the best work of satire that I have ever seen. (It is exactly as good as you would expect from an educational game.)

That aside, the story is as good as an educational story can be. Seriously, I could not imagine a story any better without leaving behind the point of the game, learning hiragana. But clearly it is not going to win any awards, story-wise. 

The soundtrack... was cool for the first few hours. Then it was a bit annoying up until the final boss fight. The tracks are not bad, but they are reused a lot. Though really none of the sound is necessary (except maybe the syllable pronunciations), so you could just mute it. However, after listening to the same tracks for hours, the new music for the final boss seemed all the more rad.

Speaking of the final boss fight. It was good. Relative to the rest of the game, it was excellent. It had a cool song, a relatively sufficient challenge, and it caught me a bit off guard (which is good). 

All in all, it is an okay game, and quite a good learning tool.

Arigatou gozaimasu!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027593021', 'num_games_owned': 1628, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 964, 'last_played': 1672978915}

author: {'steamid': '76561198297376222', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1675016595}
review:
Fena değil ancak kesinlikle bazı eksikleri var. Ben hiragana bilen biri olarak tekrar amaçlı olsun diye oynadım ve bu amaç için bayağı güzel. Hatta size kelime falan da öğretiyor bu da çok iyi. En büyük sıkıntım harflerin telafuzunu ilk kez öğrendikten sonra savaşta öğrenemeyişimiz oldu. Savaşırken harfler aklınıza kazınıyor evet ancak nasıl telafuz edeceğinizi sırf savaşlardan öğrenemiyorsunuz. Mesela her doğru cevapta harfin nasıl söylendiğini de söyleseymiş çok hoş olurmuş bence. Bir de bazı kelimeler yanlış. Mesela Noto = Not Defteri diyor ve telafuzunu da o şekilde yapıyor ancak Noto değil, Nooto olacak. Böyle küçük hatalar keşke düzeltilse.

Son olarak müzikler ve grafikler tamamen RPG Maker'ın varsayılan assetleri, yapacak bir şey yok. Oynanışı bozmadıkları için sıkıntı değil.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197971855344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1675127210}
review: Given what's avialable for quickly learning Hiragama, this game is sorely lacking.  If you're interested in learning Hiragama,  I'd strongly recommend rennshu kana flash cards on android.  The quickest way to learn the basics (which this game tries to do) is to use visual memorization, of applying images in your mind to the hiragama symbols.  In either case, if you are looking for a gamifcation method for learning basic japanese alphabets, this is not it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001802717', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1664421580}
review: As I've said in my review for the Katakana Battle game, I really admire Sleepy Duck's efforts with this game. It's fun and engaging, but the positives kind of end there. I was coupling this with duolingo lessons and I found myself abandoning this game after several hours of play because I was literally outpacing the game at learning the hiragana characters. I just think this method of learning the characters moves too slowly. I'd love to see Sleepy Duck re-approach the concept of learning with a more speed-based gameplay system. One that rewards not just accuracy, but also how fast you can knock em out. In my other review, I said that a "Typing of the Dead" style game where you knock out words, characters, and phrases under a time limit (OR DIE!) would be amazing. Sleepy Duck, please create a sequel to this series with a new set of games. I'm more than willing to throw money at you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198825856941', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1679825562}
review:
Played it for a bit over 20 hours (with Steam closed so it didn't count). Super cute ad it's exactly what the title says, a little game that teaches you hiragana, some phrases and vocabulary. Your clichee RPG game which doesn't take away its charm. Sometimes the game is a bit self-conscious like on the clichee RPG parts or with your generic character personalities. You don't have to be a gamer to make it through the game. Game mechanics are all well explained or intuitive.

I just love it when games can also be educational. It is can be greatly implemented as a new learning tool (that is as of yet still underrated) since you are forced to repeat words or hiragana in order to proceed. Great job to the creators and I am glad that this kickstarter made it as a full version onto Steam! Little tip: finish all side quests in order to make a horse appear that will tell you a cute/helpful little thing. Might as well check out the homepage that they advertise for more resources, art-books and such. (I am not paid or anything to say this I genuienly am convinced as a consumer that the stuff they put out is good.)

Not sure if Steam Cloud works with the save files so just in case backup your saves by going into the game folder under your steam folder. Or just browse local game files via the Steam interface. There is a folder called saves. Make sure to just copy the whole thing.

EDIT: For people that use 120 (approx. 140 Hz) fps monitors the game will appear incredibly fast. Couldn't find a fix for that. Maybe if you temper with some config files you'll be able to lock it at 60 fps. Disclaimer: I did not change any files at all. From a bit of experience I know that sometimes you can change some extra settings that you would not be able to edit via in game menus such as the frame lock or some other extra graphics settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561199024165500', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1665017213}
review:
일본어로 대사 쓰고 나서 아마 그걸 영어로 옯긴듯
근데 영어 번역이 개판 그냥 번역기 돌린듯
마우스로 이동 가능한 것은 일반 쯔꾸르 게임보다 이동성이 편한듯
게임 목적을 적으로 일본어가 나오는 것을 통해 안배했는데
쯔꾸르 게임 특성 상 아무래도 적과 자주 마주치게 되어 있는데
필요이상으로 동일한 히라가나와 계속 마주치는 듯한 모양새다
또한 답하는 방식이 발음과 글자를 매칭시키는 것인데
이게 히라가나 전체 발음 중에 고르게 되어 있어서 답하는 편리성이 많이 떨어진다
(객관식인데 선지가 48개라 생각하면 됨)
또한 학습이 전투를 통해 이뤄지다 보니까
답하는게 공격인데 으레 쯔꾸르에서의 전투처럼 한 적을 여러번 때리게 된다
이미 아는 답을 공격을 위해서는 여러번 동일하게 선지에서 찾아서 클릭하는 수고를 반복을 해야하고 이는 학습이 아니라 노가다다
학습을 위해서는 빠르게 다양한 글자를 접하는 것이 좋은텐데 몬스터 피통을 줄이고 퀴즈처럼 빠르게 넘어갈 수 있다면 좋았을 것 같다
또한 퀴즈다 보니까 적을 때리는 수단은 각 한가지인데
공격 선택지에서 옳게 골라놔도 적이 죽어버리면 나머지 적에게 그 공격은 먹히지 않기 때문에
턴을 그대로 날리게 된다 전투성이 안좋다
레벨업을 해도 hp 회복이 안되는 것도 까다롭다
여러 모로 전투에 퀴즈를 어거지로 쑤셔 박은거 같다
그나마 전투에서 도망치는 것이 용이하게 만들어놔서
이런 단점이 있는 전투를 스킵을 할 수 있어 다행이다
또한 묘하게 일본느낌이 섞인 듯한 BGM도 좋다

author: {'steamid': '76561198125963087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 22060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21776, 'last_played': 1708012815}
review: this game is fun and amazing

author: {'steamid': '76561198059837359', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1664135409}
review:
It's a good learning tool, but could stand to have some rough edges ironed out (You set your team's attacks, and if you set them to attack a Hiragana that's already been defeated, that's a wasted turn), it can be a bit grindy, and I have had to use an external teaching tool to reinforce the lessons because of this. But the actual lesson part is pretty solid.

I've finished this and started on Katakana War, and a lot of my criticisms seem to have been addressed there, so I feel that the series is well worth it if you're attempting to learn Japanese, so you can tackle the characters first and then words and sentences.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144427989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1153, 'last_played': 1491385498}

Great game! It's a fun, nicely fleshed out JRPG that actually did a fantastic job of teaching me to recognize hiragana characters more quickly. This game is definitely appropriate for Japanese beginners or complete newbies but those who just need to brush up will also get a ton of value from playing.

The price is astoundingly good for the experience that's delivered. Superb!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132822374', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1661599350}
