author: {'steamid': '76561198020128237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1661906871}
review:
This game is AWESOME!

A little polish to the very clunky game mechanics and this would be amazing.
What I'd like to see is groupings, so you dont have to scroll around and dig through dozens of hiragana to find what you're looking for. Also, WASD support... I havent had to use my arrow keys since the 90s. Finally, make the mouse a little more useful in the menus please! One click confirm, right click to go back!

If you've ever wanted to learn a new language, Japanese or not, this is the way it should be done!

author: {'steamid': '76561198241979072', 'num_games_owned': 1198, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1655694944}
review:
In my opinion, what this game offers can be found elsewhere in more effective fashion for free. Honestly, it took me two days to learn hiragana and katakana from DuoLingo and then I moved onto JLAB and Anki decks to work on vocabulary and focus on grammar. Granted, I didn't give this game several hours of my time or anything, but for the time I did give it, I feel like I would have been better off spending it cracking down and memorizing the hiragana without the tedium of playing a turn-based JRPG on top of it. 

I'm sure it'll work well for some people, and to those people I say more power to you (and congratulations for taking the first step to learning a new language), but for my money, I suggest expending as many of the free resources as you can before trying something like this. It's no more effective than any other method of study and if the layer of gamification doesn't help to grab your attention, you're really no further ahead than you would be with another program. 

I appreciate what the developers were going for, and I wish them all the best, but if you're anything at all like I am, this probably won't do much for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061635334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1659913173}

author: {'steamid': '76561198372470192', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1656252367}
review: Если бы в стиме имелась нейтральная оценка, то я бы такую этой игре и поставил. Исходя из своего опыта, могу сказать, что мне игра не сильно помогла в изучении хираганы. За 5 часов я хоть и дошёл до N-звуков, но помнил от силы лишь 10 символов, однако с видосов на ютубе мой прогресс шёл куда быстрее. Не могу никому на 100% посоветовать эту игру, ибо тут уже всё индивидуально. Всё же, если вы тоже испытываете проблему с изучением хираганы через игру, то лучше посмотрите видео japanesepod и не долбите себе мозги. Хирагану и катакану за недели три освоить вполне можно (ну и попрактиковать тоже, ибо после окончания обучения всё же иногда путаешься в некоторых символах)

author: {'steamid': '76561198192914125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1404, 'last_played': 1659657489}
review:
Great old school style RPG for learning Hiragana. I used this with other physical and online resource to learn Japanese and find the method of using different char/fonts as a positive because in the real world, you would see different fonts and handwriting for the char. Just beat the game and the way they did the ending was a great way to finish the game and use what you learn. 

At first I started this game to learn but at the end, I am now missing the characters that I bonded with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279140910', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 406, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1659465173}
review:
This game is best used as a tool to practice, rather than an introduction (That's because there are 46 characters in total to memorise) 
 
Personally I've used youtube videos with mnemonics first, then duolingo, then this game. 

All that counts is exposure, if you want to learn and play at the same time look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198346149743', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1660920290}

review: I won't lie, the game is kind of clunky and it isn't the best thing out there. However, it's still a very nice and fun tool to use while learning Hiragana. Although, I do recommend pairing this game with some other form of learning. Such as a flashcard app or Hiragana browser games to help your memory. All in all, I enjoyed it and it really helped to refresh my memory in a fun way. I think kids especially could benefit from educational games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198434491068', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 834, 'last_played': 1640235014}

review:
PROS
+ Good for learning and reinforcing Hiragana.
+ Epic final dungeon and boss battle.
+ Late-game changes enemies and battle flow.

CONS
- Quite grindy with little in-game rewards.
- Lots of backtracking for sidequests and dungeon progression.
- Encounter rate can be insane sometimes, but you can always escape.

OVERALL
Recommend. When you get past the rough edges, it's definitely a good learning resource.

Arkada oyun ve ses devam etmesine rağmen görüntüyü vermiyor. Herkeste yaşanan bir sorun değil ve çözümünü de bulamadım. Steamde buglı oyunlafrın bulunması çok komik ve saçma gerçekten.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963583718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1656421769}
review:
A very marginal thumbs up for this Japanese learning RPGmaker game.

The good:
It's dirt cheap, especially on sale.
This game covers all hiragana characters, some basic vocabulary and touches on a few cultural points as well.
The old school turn-based combat should be familiar to anyone who's ever played RPGs like Final Fantasy.

The meh:
Loot could've been better and there could've been more of it.
The music and graphics are typical RPGmaker. Not bad, but nothing special.
The story is pretty silly, but as a framework for study, it gets the job done.

The bad:
I was honestly surprised at how punishing and tedious the combat is in the late game. You're unlikely to be able to handle 2-3 encounters before slinking back to an inn to recharge. This led me to run away from a lot of random encounters just to finish my quests, which meant later I had to grind more than I wanted to.
There are also some frustrating combat mechanics. For example, in Final Fantasy, if you use two characters to target one enemy, and your first attack ends up killing them, the second attack will reorient to the nearest surviving enemy. Not so here, that second attack ends up being wasted.
Finding the correct answers from a huge list of possible characters during combat isn't really that fun, to be honest. I wish there had been another way.

Verdict:
As a language teacher myself (and someone who has spent 15 years in Japan), I'd say it's a decent tool for beginners learning Japanese, and it's a cheap way to practice. But the game as a game leaves much to be desired.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313647961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1656378575}
review:
This game crashes??? Like really? 
Also the first game crashes my computer......unbelievable.
  
Story is not the point since its just teaching us hiragana.
But the game flow is really bad. The menu is not convenient. 
Show the health bar of the characters, always hitting wrong ones because the last one died.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060054098', 'num_games_owned': 2929, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1656288607}
review:
It's alright. It teaches you how to write and pronounce hiragana, which is really cool, but the whole "game" aspect of this (i.e. combat and exploration) is kind of pointless, and even frustrating at times.

Personally, I prefer to learn a foreign language in a different way, but if this is your cup of tea, that's fine, you can give it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118997006', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1656107763}
review:
Story, gameplay...this game sucks, maybe it's great to learn hiragana, but after lesson 4 these hiragana things started stomping me hard. I prefer using language learning apps, youtube, or whatever instead of playing this very boring game 
I'm not grinding on such a game, lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198190565041', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1071, 'last_played': 1654198326}
review:
Данная игра не представляет из себя ничего. Плохой баланс, где нужно хоть немного да погриндить (буквально час, может меньше), а то и пару боёв не выстоишь, сюжет посредственный, нету кнопки выхода из игры (что?). Саунд в городе и в меню игры такой, что очень быстро приедается и начинает негативные эмоции вызывать. Да, здесь в зависимости от локации меняются мелодии, но в целом посредственные. Боевка, на мой взгляд, даже смотря на то, что это JRPG, однообразная, умения практически не используешь. Сайд квесты слабые и по типу "возьми-принеси". При этом, наверное единственным плюсом является диалоги. Мне показались они какими-то тёплыми и реальными.

НО, это если смотреть на игру как развлекательную, в которую ты играешь для получения эмоций. Теперь я бы хотел рассказать об игре как обучающую, в которой ты учишь новое.
Данная игра, на мой взгляд, в целом неплохая для того, чтобы начать изучать японский и её систему писания, в этой части Хирагану. Тут нас проводят по каждому символу, рассказывают как правильно его произносить и как писать. Помимо этого пополняют наш словарный запас и учат простым, но полезным фразам по типу "Меня зовут ...". В то же время сайд квесты дополнительно дают нам новый материал для изучения. Из минусов я выделю момент, где учат писать символ. Мне показалось неудобным, что при анимации написания используется один шрифт, а после неё другой шрифт, приходилось мне несколько раз пересматривать. Можно, как вариант, было показывать оба шрифта: зацикленную анимацию написания одним шрифтом и другой шрифт. Ещё не понравилось, что был слишком тихий голос произношения символов/слов/фраз при том что музыка громко, а в настройках кнопки уменьшения громкости этой музыки я не нашёл, хотя вариантов там было много. Так же условно говоря через пару глав символы, что ты изучил, начинают очень редко попадаться и из-за этого можешь понемногу начинать их забывать.
Поэтому для начального изучения я в целом могу порекомендовать эту игру, для других целей - нет.

author: {'steamid': '76561198244146996', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1654052479}
review: Very good game, keeps you interested while learning. I started this game with 3 weeks of studying hiragana already with actual books (Genki I, Tae Kim) and the sort, which can be bit boring. This little game helped me polish what I was missing, like confusing lookalikes, diacritics, particles (tho it didn't explain in detail) etc. The game throws useful words too via side quests mostly, useful phrases as well. It's not a learn Japanese in 2 hours type of thing, this is a very small fraction of what Japanese is, so it's very basic, baby steps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032132376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1651065217}

author: {'steamid': '76561197974998697', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1651389251}
review:
[b]All of my criticisms of this game have been implemented in Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War and I will be positively reviewing that game when I'm done with it.[/b]

[b]DISCLAIMER:[/b]: I played 16 hours on PC, but then I copied the game to my phone and used JoiPlay to play it since it's an RPGMaker game. I have 24 hours in total as of writing this review. https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=cyou.joiplay.joiplay&hl=en_US&gl=US

I did not read keyofw's review (https://steamcommunity.com/id/keyofw/recommended/438270/) before writing a draft of my own, but we share many of the same points.

1. No Vocalization when Selecting Sounds

In Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War, attacking with katakana plays the sound of that katakana. In Kanji Combat, when you select a kanji, it plays the kun'yomi or on'yomi of the kanji. This is fantastic game design because every battle reinforces these sounds and you begin to associate the sounds with the kana.

This game does not do that. The only time it plays the sounds of each character is during the lessons. Since the sounds are already in the game, it shouldn't take the developers that much time to have the players play each hiragana sound when attacking.

2. List of Hiragana Attacks is Unintuitive

In Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War/Kanji Combat, there are 5 kana on each row. The game should have had something like this: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiragana#/media/File:Table_hiragana.svg

Instead it's:

a i
u e
o ka
ki ku
ke ko
ga gi
gu ge
go sa
shi su
se so
za ji
zu ze
zo ta
chi tsu
te to
da ji (d)
zu (d) de
...

You get it, it's a PAIN to scroll all the way up and all the way down. They should have used 10 columns with the dakuten and ん in rows below the main hiragana.

3. ん was not taught first

There are many words in the vocabulary that the game cannot properly teach you because it didn't introduce the most basic Hiragana, ん, first, but rather last. For instance, it taught that senpai is し-n-か-n-せ-n. No one is going to go back and actually re-learn/re-read the proper hiragana you're just going to have to learn it by hearing the word.

4. Hiragana enemies are not randomized

As keyofw pointed out, the groups of hiragana warriors are predefined instead of truly being randomized. Each group has the same hiragana so there's a weigh as to which hiragana you'll see most more than others, which leaves you with blind spots for the hiragana you see the least.

5. English enemies only show up twice

Reverse enemies only show up twice, once in the coffins and once on the boat. There should have been reverse enemies for EVERY stage of the game! I got very, very good at clicking ぬ nu, ね ne, no の, but if I just saw "ne" I couldn't actually picture ね in my head.

6. Small Gameplay Issues - Items and Map

You have to buy a mirror for a sidequest alongside several other items once you reach Tokyo, and none of the items seem to have a purpose other than you're supposed to guess which one is a mirror? It would have been better if each item had a purpose and then you'd have a need to memorize what the name of each one was. Doubly so, Ramune and other items should have been called Ramune (らむね) as a way of getting you used to the Hiragana characters before you encounter them.

When you leave Snowmass Village, you leave from the top but your characters spawn at the bottom, so if you hold down the Up button you just infinitely go in and out of the town. Several other locations are like this and just a complete pain to get in and out of, like Tokyo and Mt. Fuji.

7. The Plot Was Lacking

Without spoiling anything, what was the dynamic between Noburo and his sister? What were their individual objectives? If Noburo had said, "I want to make the world fear and hate hiragana!" that would have been more convincing as a bad guy. Or it would have been even better if he said, "I've been sent by Japan to conquer your country!" and then you find out once you travel to Japan that he's a lone actor. Basically could have made it where Noburo is carrying out false flag attacks and you have to prevent war by revealing it. Instead you get... *spoiler*.

8. No "Castle"/"Treehouse" or Endgame Content

Once again, in Katakana War/Kanji Combat, there is a a castle/treehouse where you can battle it out with all of the kana that you've encountered this far. This is NOTHING close to this in Hiragana Battle. There's no place where you can test your skill against each and every single hiragana that you've encountered. The best you get is Grim Tower where you fight whole words. The first level or two of the Grim Tower should have been random assortments of hiragana. I found that once I finished learning all of them, I started to forget all of the k-, g- s-, and z- hiragana, or confuse them for each other. I could have used a refresher towards the end.

Also, not all of the vocab words even show up in the Grim Tower.

Lastly, after you defeat Noburo, if you climb back to the top of The Grim Tower you cannot face him in combat again to test your knowledge of words, and your four spirtes are stuck on the top floor like doppelgangers. The game also deletes all items from your inventory (but not weapons or armor). Clearly bugs and quite depressing. I'm glad I didn't override my save from right before I beat him.

[hr][/hr]

tl;dr: If you want to learn Hiragana, grab a book and write each character once a day for several days while verbalizing them. You will learn Hiragana very quickly, much faster than playing this game.

This game has potential, but after 6 years it very badly needs an update. The audio files for each hiragana are already in the game so the devs could fix that, and they could also fix the UI to allow better selection of hiragana.

For those who say this is too much criticism for a $7 game, this game is for all intents and purposes a prequel to Katakana Battle and Kanji Combat, and should be played before the other two, so I have to review this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042620952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1382, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1651188935}
review:
[h1] Genre [/h1] Eine Mischung aus Bildung & JRPG

[h1] Story [/h1] Ein böser Japanischer Magier namens "Noburo" hat mit Hilfe von Portalen seine Hiragana Krieger auf unser Land losgelassen und die einzige Möglichkeit Noburo und seine Schergen aufzuhalten, ist es japanisch zu lernen, spezifisch "Hiragana" das japanische Alphabet

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] Man kann dieses Spiel wirklich gut nutzen um tatsächlich Hiragana zu lernen. Zudem lernt man auch einige Grund Vokabeln & Sätze aus dem Japanischen. Alles wird sehr gut und verständlich erklärt, allerdings alles auf Englisch, also wenn man mit der Englischen Sprache nicht wirklich klar kommt dann bringt es hier gar nichts. Wir lernen nach und nach die Einzelnen Buchstaben/Zeichen. Es ist auch sehr wichtig das man sich alles notiert, denn sonst wird es schwierig werden voran zu kommen. Nach jeder Lerneinheit, werden wir irgendwo hingeschickt um die Quelle der Hiragana Krieger zu finden und Noburo aufzuhalten. Die Kämpfe sind Random Encounter und alle Gegner sind Hiragana Zeichen, diese können wir nur besiegen, wenn wir den richtigen Englischen Buchstaben oder manchmal auch andersrum (Gegner sind Englische Buchstaben und wir müssen dann das jeweilige Hiragana Zeichen auswählen). Gegen Ende des Spiels müssen wir diese mit Sätze bekämpfen bzw. übersetzen. Man kann natürlich auch ganz JRPG typisch, neue Waffen und auch Ausrüstung für seine 4 Party Member finden & auch kaufen um sie stärker werden zu lassen. Es gibt auch einige simple Nebenquests zu lösen. Wenn man diese gelöst hat, bringt der Auftraggeber/in uns Neue Wörter bei. Musik ist ordentlich wie immer bei diesen RPGMaker spielen

[h1] Pro/Contra [/h1]
+ Story OK
+ Musik ordentlich
+ Nette Einführung wenn man Hiragana und/oder Japanisch allgemein lernen möchte
+ Es wird verständlich erklärt (aber nur in Englisch)
+ Einige Nebenquests wodurch man Neue Japanische Wörter lernen kann
+ Netter Endboss Kampf
+ Sammelkarten
+ Xbox 360 Controller Support

- Leider keine Achievements
- Bei solchen Lern/Bildungsspielen wäre es schöner wenn man mehrere Sprachen als nur Englisch hätte

[h1] Fazit [/h1] Ein wirklich sehr schönes Lern/Bildungsspiel gemischt mit einem JRPG. Mir hat es sehr gut gefallen. Man muss sich natürlich für die Japanische Sprache oder Japan allgemein interessieren um hiermit Spaß haben zu können aber warum sollte man es kaufen/spielen wenn man es nicht lernen möchte, das wäre ja merkwürdig. Ich persönlich interessiere mich sehr für Japan und kannte auch einige Wörter/Sätze bereits. Wer lust hat zu lernen, der ist mit diesem Spiel gut bedient weil hier alles schön & verständlich erklärt wird und durch das JRPG Setting lernt man auch schneller bzw. intensiver weil man ja voran kommen will. Ich kann es also jedem Empfehlen der sich für Japanische Sprache interessiert und es immer schon einmal lernen wollte. Dieses Spiel ist ein sehr netter Einstieg

author: {'steamid': '76561198199984294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1651033314}
review:
This was well worth the time. Learn Japanese to Survive is looking like a very helpful tool to learn Japanese for people like me who don't do so well with reading. If I had to read books and use websites for each hiragana I would have quit after the vowels. I've always wanted to learn Japanese but stopped ether because of the stigma around learning Japanese or I'd lose interest. This kept my interest for 16. hours plus what ever I spent outside of the game to help memorize the hiragana. (Note: In game clock is fast and not accurate)

TLDR: If you aren't good with learning from books give this a go. I should have gone through with this series back in my sophomore year. Oh well.

Score 10/10. Not the best rpg but your not playing for the rpg. Your playing to learn and this dose it as extremely well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189356449', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1650408272}
review:
Parto subito con due premesse per questa recensione: 

-ho più di 25 minuti poiché ho giocato quasi due ore da un mio amico 

-ho giocato questo gioco più per consigliarlo che per usarlo poiché so già a memoria sia l'Hiragana che anche il Katakana, inoltre conosco una buona quantità di caratteri Kanji. 

questo gioco ha solo una ed un unica funziona, ovvero insegnare nel modo più semplice (ed anche divertente) per imparare l'alfabeto più importante giapponese, ovvero l'hiragana. 

il gioco è fatto in rpg maker e ha una trama e una grafica assolutamente mediocri. 

il gameplay invece ammetto che è interessante, in breve si riassume in un viaggio dove i nostri nemici sono dei caratteri in Hiragana e l'unico modo per sconfiggerli è sapere a quale lettera dell'alfabeto internazionale corrisponde (o Romanji per i più precisini). 

devo dire che per il suo scopo ci riesce alla perfezione, riesce a rendere immersiva l'avventura e l'insegnamento di questo fantastico alfabeto molto divertente, apprezzo inoltre che hanno inserito anche i dakuten e le varie combinazioni.

consiglio il gioco solo e solamente a chi vuole imparare l'Hiragana, 

Voto: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198106304062', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1650165144}
review:
This game is good for a role-playing game. I've been playing it for a few days. The only thing I wish is if it reads you the text instead of you reading it like it does when it reads you the letters, especially for someone like me who reads under average, this can slow me down a little bit when actually playing, I also don't like reading and prefer more visuals like a Disney movie or video games. So, I can't be in a class setting for learning a language (I already tried Spanish for a day in school, LOL) That didn't work, luckily, I got removed. The other thing I noticed in the game is that when it brings you to Japan which is normal when you go into Japan in real life (so that is understandable) is that it shows you Japanese words that have not been taught yet. So, I can't even buy them in the convenience store for not knowing what it is, LOL. That is how far I got into the game. 🙂

I also have a bad memory but hopefully one day I can fully read the language. I know most hiragana. But I have difficulties with katakana so far and I haven't even looked at Kanji yet. Learning it over and over again will help. It will also help if you surround yourself with the language especially from what you already know and take little steps at a time. I've been interested in Japan since I was in high school from what I see on TV and future technology. I'm now a young adult, still don't know the language, LOL. I haven't mentioned this yet, but I am on the autism spectrum. So, this is an autistic review of the game. Sayonara. 😎

author: {'steamid': '76561198023352806', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1656264324}
review: Even if learning Japanese isn't your main goal, this is a solid RPG in its own right. It's fun, straight forward, and easy to narrate making it a great stream option. It's a great variety option for streamers and helps if you're looking to learn Japanese as the battles force you to use the right sounds to impact the enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183442181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1649298342}
review: Use this combined with Duolingo and you will learn the characters and pronunciations super fast. This game is more for developing the skill to recognize the symbols and understanding the sounds without having to think so much about it. Duolingo focuses more on teaching you words and phrases which this game does not. That is not to say that it is not apart of the game. It just isn't a massive part of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198366056677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3783, 'last_played': 1701861941}
review:
I first played Hiragana Battle in 2017, subsequently played the two other Learn Japanese To Survive games, and recently revisited this one for some light revision.

Like the JRPGs that inspired Hiragana Battle's gameplay, it can get tedious when walking through dungeons. Triggering encounters every few steps when you just want to explore/leave can be frustrating. The advantage Hiragana Battle has over other JRPGs is being able to tell yourself that you're learning from the infuriating frequency of the fights. You're going to know these Hiragana characters reeaaalllyyyy well! (Admittedly, this is undermined on the occasions when you get the exact same group of enemies multiple times in a row and just input the same response without thinking.)

A flaw in Hiragana Battle's turn-based system is having to choose every party member's actions at the beginning of the round, which prevents you from reacting to unforeseen events. For example, a particular enemy might be defeated more quickly than you expected, so one of your characters might end up looking like a right plonker by trying to attack them. It's easy to work with the system though because the fights are simple and therefore predictable, which I expect is intentional since this is a learning tool. The battles have some basic JRPG elements like status effects to keep it interesting, but the overall simplicity keeps your focus on recalling Hiragana characters rather than strategising.

Making the game engaging without distracting you from studying is well balanced throughout. The main storyline provides the motivation for your quest but it's basic enough that you will stay focused on your studies rather than pondering the plot. The game has fun locations to explore, side quests to complete and NPCs to chat to, and the majority of these contribute to your Japanese learning - which includes some beginner vocabulary and grammar as well as Hiragana. All the study materials and opportunities to practise are well integrated into the gameplay, and you are able to revisit them as much as you need to. I love studying Japanese this way :)

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/fayestrawberry/] Faye Strawberry Curator [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198094109964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1647024562}
review:
I want to be as transparent as possible in this review so some disclaimers and notes first of all:

- I didn't complete this game. I think I got about halfway in? For anyone that's played it (very minor spoiler), [spoiler]I got to the part just before you leave on the boat to Japan.[/spoiler]

- I already knew hiragana before playing this game. Why even play this game then do you ask? Because I'm still a complete newb in my journey of learning Japanese. I thought this game would be a good way to help me continue to memorise hiragana. I also heard the game teaches some vocabulary, not just hiragana, which it does.

- I will mostly be reviewing this title from the viewpoint of it primarily being a learning tool, rather than a game. But I will touch on its actual gameplay value a bit as well.

Anyhow, now we've gotten that out of the way, let's get onto the actual review.

[h1]How effective is this game for learning hiragana?[/h1]

Everyone learns things differently; some methods may be more effective for some people, and those same methods may prove nightmarish to others. So it's always kind of hard to grade just how effective a certain learning tool or method is, because some people may find it difficult, others may find it enjoyable and easy to understand.

This being a review and all, I'll be judging its effective based on my own opinions and experiences. So your mileage may vary.

The way the game teaches you hiragana is primarily by showing you a character, describing how it's pronounced (accompanied by a rather robotic voice), and how to draw it. The game seems to expect you to be actually physically drawing these characters into a notepad as you go along.

I personally do NOT think this is an effective way of learning hiragana. I personally found it a lot easier to grasp by having mnemonics associated with each character, and using a SRS (spaced repetition system) with flashcards to drill into my head how each character was pronounced. I used a site called Tofugo for this, though there's probably other sites that have mnemonics for each hiragana character, or you can maybe even come up with some of your own if you've imaginative enough.

If you're unsure what a mnemonic is or want a visual example, then picture this: The hiragana し (shi) looks a bit like a [shi]eld, with an arm sticking out the right, holding it up.

But pushing aside my own views on what's the "best" way to learn and memorise hiragana, there's some issues with how the game presents its hiragana lessons.

First of all, as I already mentioned, it plays a very robotic voice to give you an audio demonstration of how each hiragana is pronounced. It can actually be quite hard to understand at times, sometimes it says things far too quickly, and being robotic, it just doesn't really sound natural.

Secondly, it displays a different font when showing writing animations for the hiragana. This can be confusing, especially when some characters look different as a result. For example, り is shown being written with a break at the top. Think of it like the number 4 when written with an open top (like on an old school calculator). It's not incorrect, but it can be a bit jarring for a complete beginner, especially since it doesn't explain these differences at all.

Thirdly, the game does teach you some vocab along with hiragana. A lot of this is learnt via doing side quests, which you can completely ignore if you so choose. My main issue with them though, is that a lot of them just give you the romaji translations for these words. Which isn't terrible early on, but the sooner you can actually read these Japanese words in their native characters, even if it is just in hiragana (as opposed to kanji), the better.

And finally, when the game does teach you some vocabulary in the mandatory, non-optional side quests part of the game, it has a weird tendency to teach you words with characters it hasn't already taught you. So いぬ (inu) will become い-nu. It feels very unnatural and I don't really know why they decided to do this. Maybe this is just a personal pet peeve more than anything though.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]

This is a cookie cutter RPG maker game. The game on its own, judging it simply from the viewpoint of it being a game is... Not very good. You have several atrocious looking maze areas, a rather high rate of random encounters, generic music, art and presentation, a lacklustre plot and characters, rather boring combat, and frequently having to back track through an area to get something you couldn't get previously until the game told you you can.

A lot of this can be forgiven because, at the end of the day, the game itself is just a tool to teach. The main focus is not the game itself after all, but it is [b]still[/b] a game, so it's hard to ignore all its misgivings, especially once you've already logged a single digit hours into the game.

Anyway, as aforementioned, the game tries to reinforce the hiragana it teaches you in its lessons through the battles you face in random encounters. The concept is simple: You see a hiragana warrior that corresponds with the English translation NA (for example), so you browse through a catalogue of these hiragana translations, select the correct one, select the correct warrior and bam, you can deal damage to it. Get it wrong? You do zero damage.

How it usually works is: The game teaches you a set of hiragana characters, and then thrusts you into a new area where you have to do something or other, maybe defeat a boss at the end, and like any standard ol' RPG with random encounters, you'll encounter battles throughout these areas. The enemy hiragana warriors in each area usually correspond to the most recent hiragana you've learnt.

I did encounter a very glaring problem with this though. The "enemies" in random encounters seem to be preset groupings. I thought at first maybe it was coincidence but it happened far too many times for that to be the case. Say you encounter a group of へ, は and ぴ hiragana characters... But then you encounter this exact same grouping, in the same order no less, in the next battle, or maybe the next battle after. This becomes a recurring problem, and it often ends up you just mashing the exact same buttons you did in a previous encounter, in the exact same order, over and over.

This becomes kinda old, kinda fast. And with how frequent the random encounters were, sometimes entering a battle every 3 steps, and the game loves to waste your time with its horrible twisty maze areas that you have to navigate almost in their entirety if you want all the chests, you will be encountering the same groupings of hiragana over, and over, and over. It didn't even feel like I was really looking at the hiragana and recalling their English translations after a time, it was just going through the motions of clicking these same "attacks" (the English translations) on the same characters and then moving onto the next encounter within the next 5 seconds.

It became so tedious that I ended up dropping the game. I didn't really feel like I was learning anything any more, and certainly wasn't have any fun. This is my primary reason for the negative review.

[h1]Conclusion/Should I buy this?[/h1]

If you're interested in this game because you're looking for a fun game or a fun way to learn Japanese, you'll probably find yourself very disappointed (especially on the former by itself).

If you're looking for "fast" ways to learn hiragana, then definitely steer clear of this game. And if everything else I've described about it doesn't appeal to you, then that's another reason to probably avoid this one.

If what I described about how the game teaches you DOES appeal to you, then definitely check it out, but it goes on sale a lot, for dirt cheap, so I recommend buying it during one of its many discounts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021215473', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1646768273}
review:
Nice videogame to practice Hiragana ひらがな

The game has all the basics to teach you how to read and type hiragana.
I highly recommend you take pen and paper and start taking notes on them, writing them and how to pronounce them to help memorize them. Do NOT look at your notes when fighting hiragana, learn by practice and error.

Some things I did not like is when the game shows you new vocabulary with letters that have not been explained yet and when it shows you words in hiragana that are not typed actually in hiragana but in katakana. Yes, you can read them in hiragana but it is not correct and may lead to future confusion. Of course you will not know which ones are them if you don't know katakana.

Other than that the game is fun, I personally enjoyed reading the shop items in hiragana and translating them on my own. (You will find these shops when you travel somewhere else, to avoid spoilers...)

Now, I will start with Katakana Battle!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046909876', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1644195090}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive - Hiragana Battle is a fun way to review and test your knowledge of hiragana characters and a few basic vocabulary words. Overall a good game, and helped with my recall, especially for hiragana that look similar (る・ろ；わ・れ）

A few items that I did find frustrating: 
[list][*]There's no way to skip reviews, so if you want to replay it, you'll have to sit through the tutorials again.
[*]Having to lock in responses for the round: When my characters were on the cusp of being able to one-shot hiragana, it was frustrating to have them take it out, and then the next character to do no damage because they had to whack a character that they hadn't been locked in on. Could have possibly been circumvented by just doing a general lock/identification of each hiragana, and if it was correct, the characters did damage in sequence. 
[*]Written vs. font character styles: When doing the writing practice, you can see the stroke order animation, which is great, but in cases where the typed font and written styles differ (example: き　or ふ), I wish that they would keep the written style on the screen while you are practicing so you can compare without having to continue to click the animation. There was tons of free space on the screen, so they could have been side-by-side.
[*]Choosing words that should be presented in katakana. The game does acknowledge that words like "coffee" and "pen" should be in katakana, and wouldn't be written in hiragana. It would be better to not select those particular vocab words for this game at all, in that case. 
[/list]

review: O jogo possui uma jogabilidade simples e nostálgica que relembra muito o Pokémon e o Final Fantasy de GameBoy. Mesmo o jogo sendo todo em inglês, o mesmo é usado de uma forma básica e formal não sendo um obstáculo que impeça o jogador de aprender o japonês (um dos alfabetos). A trilha sonora, os gráficos e os itens/ferramentas de RPG são usados como segundo plano para dar uma base sólida ao principal foco que é te ensinar o alfabeto Hiragana, podendo até ser apreciados durante a sua jogatina e aprendizagem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040811698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1641685268}
review:
Absolutely worth it on sale for anyone interested in learning to read and write hiragana. I also found Tofugu's guide ( https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-hiragana/ ) to be very beneficial alongside this. You will learn the hiragana in no time and have fun doing it. I recommend taking breaks after every couple lessons to give time to sink in and recall.

+Teaches all the hiragana
+Teaches some basic phrases and vocabulary
+Art style, character models, backgrounds
+Music
+Battles reinforce the learning
+Story elements make it fun
+Weapon and armor upgrades
+Side quests add extra vocabulary

-Underdeveloped characters
-Skills are not balanced between male/female characters
-Random battles every few steps
-Enemy groups are not random, so can be memorized
-RPG menu system is clunky for input

author: {'steamid': '76561198070430902', 'num_games_owned': 988, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1635796267}
review:
I don't have much say. [spoiler] After writing the whole opinion - so that was a lie [/spoiler]
After a month, I still have problems with reading Hiragana (e.x. sometimes misreading na with ra and vice versa; ya/yu not entirely remembered).
17 A5 pages. The worst thing here, probably, is pretty often break from train of thoughts. If you want to revise and bring the material to perfection, you should choose fights with Hiragana warriors. Concept of that kind of learning is really promising. Even mildly distracted, you may achieve a lot, but it's still too slow.
Fight (slow, btw.) -> over a dozen of seconds to meet another enemy -> maybe the same enemies (RNG in this game sux).

In 1-5 scale it lands in middle.
3/5
I know that this engine is quite old so I do not blame developer/s for that, but I don't get at least two things.
  1st: You have "items" to revise lessons (1-10) - why can't you use them during the fight. You have to lose/flee  from the battle to revise them, right? And because of that, I used them only once - to check them. They weren't even complete (didn't have handwriting revision or how to spell them - either one).
  2nd: Developer/s didn't have problem with putting 15 characters into one lesson, but did have problem with 6 characters, so they've been splitted to two lessons (9/10 lesson). At the end, you just want to finish the game so it would be nice to have w-'s, y-'s and n together.
  3rd: Alternative world parts are too short and you cannot return to them. The problem I'm having is that I can mostly read hiragana, but writing (you're already thinking in Romaji so it goes from Romaji to Hiragana) is pain and it requires more thinking/concentration from me than only reading Hiragana.

As far as I see, it took me 17,7h to complete the game (but I spent some time AFK so maybe 16-17h total)

review: It's a bit corny, but it's amusing, and fun. I enjoy it. Kinda quirky for what it's trying to do, it's good at it. The repetitive nature of random encounter battles really suits the sort of study-like mechanics of memorisation you'd expect when doing language. That fact that I'm not a 100% beginner did become a negative in some respects, such as, I did get annoyed that I couldn't skip the repeated examples of how to write each new kana and their explanations, etc. However, as of creating this review, I had made it over 3hrs in and have yet to come across anything that made the game non enjoyable for an above beginner student.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006891778', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1636426896}
review:
To lower expectations, this is not an intensive exploration of hiragana, but it is a start. You're not required to write things down (although it may be helpful to jog your memory); you'll get plenty of practice far more than running into Zubats in caves on a Gameboy Pokemon game. There is a short storyline that guides you through what you will be dealing with, and so far it really just covers the basics of the kana and gives you a few words to learn. It does not, whether for better or for worse, go over all of the basics of grammar, beyond the few examples. That's just for informative purposes.

For me as a beginner, it wasn't stressful to learn, and thanks to the drilling in game, I was still able to manage it through the end. Mistakes and the combat become more forgivable with practice. In what it was lacking, I was able to find more practice from outside resources and be comfortable with reading the kana. I'd expect the same across the other 2 kanas, and combine that knowledge to be better at the language.

With that being said, for a beginner, this is a decent introduction to the language. It's simple, short, and to the point. While that can come with some caveats, there is no demand for high pace. You progress as you learn and use hiragana to play the game so that it would be easier to move on to advanced materials on your own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040373707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1637213892}
review: The game teaches solid basics and has you review them in a fun way. You get the repetition without the tedium. It also does not hold you back with game mechanics. If you feel you have a good enough grasp of the material, you can skip past the small fights and head straight for the boss quiz. I liked this game, and look forward to Katakana War.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 603, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1636843882}
review:
This is the first entry in the Learn Japanese To Survive trilogy, a series of games designed to assist players in learning the 3 Japanese writing systems: Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji. This first title is dedicated to Hiragana, which makes sense since it’s the foundation and most basic system of the 3, so the best starting point.
As an educational tool, it’s alright, but isn’t enough by itself. It guides the player in using a notebook for writing the characters and corresponding romaji, while gradually introducing the characters in lessons spread throughout the game. It teaches you how to write them, and the sound associated with them. Thing is, you’ll probably look at the notes a lot, which doesn’t help much with memorizing. For effective learning, you need other tools and find your own learning pace, but I suppose the game is limited in what it can do. It does what it can. It also teaches you some vocabulary and other rules, but they’re even worse because they’re barely used in-game, they’re mostly exposition.
As a game, unfortunately, it’s a generic RPG-maker title. The only main difference in combat is that there’s no generic attack. Instead, you need to answer with the correct romaji that matches the enemy Hiragana character. But that’s the main mechanic of the game to teach you. Sometimes it will reverse the matching, and only at the end you need to answer with words. Combat is repetitive, but I suppose it helps you memorize through repetition. It’ll get annoying though, especially because the random encounter rate is too high. You can escape most encounters at least. Everything else is just meh. There’re abilities and items you’ll rarely use, weapons and armor with stronger stats over time, generic dungeons with generic loot, and an alright story that lasts around 10 hours. At least there’re some side quests, but they’re nothing special. They teach you some more stuff though. As an RPG, it’s nothing you haven’t played before, the only difference is replacing generic attacks with answers. No, it’s even worse, because it lacks other elements, like AOEs and status effects on enemies (they’re only applied on the party), so combat lacks variety. It feels lackluster overall.
All combined, while I can see the potential of creating a game that is simultaneously a teaching tool, it lacks in both areas. In the teaching I guess it can’t improve much further. But as a game it could’ve been much more and be something more engaging. Still, I like the idea, and it’s engaging. And since it’s something I haven’t seen before, I can recommend it for cheap if you want to get introduced to the Japanese language and writing system. I would give it a neutral review, if possible, but I was entertained by it, and I’ve played worse before. I was just disappointed by it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057944212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1556188741}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013240999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1632631690}
review: So, I will be up front about this. I recommend this as a learning tool for Hiragana, however, only in the context that you know that you are able to learn through games. I have unfortunately discovered that I do not learn this way. If you are an absolute beginner this series of games is entirely built around that, so if you want to learn Japanese from the bottom up and this is a good learning method for you I 100% recommend this. Otherwise, find a way to learn that will fit your learning style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041163778', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1626732742}
review:
There are many, many ways to start learning Japanese. This game was a very good introduction to getting you used to reading, hearing, and importantly, writing the Hiragana characters. For me, this, along with memory apps like Hiragana Pro, helped me recognize the kana very quickly.

However, the detracting points from this game can end up being the RPG elements. After a point I just wanted to learn the language, not play the game, and so I moved onto other methods. However, this game gave me a great introduction and a couple of minutes play for a few nights really sped up my learning.

If you really want to start learning Japanese and want a comfortable start, grab a notebook, download Hiragana Pro, and take your notes until you learn the kana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020304960', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1630381342}
review:
This is the kind of resource I wish I'd had access to when I was first on the initial hurdle of learning hiragana. If you are just starting out learning Japanese and you're finding hiragana to be a barrier, you can't do much better than this game which turns something daunting into something fun. 

However, if you already know hiragana, I can only recommend this game with some reservations. I'm at the intermediate level, so for me it was far too basic to be educational. That said, it's a charming game with calming music and nostalgic pixel-art visuals similar to early Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest. It's not as mechanically good as those games though. The battle system is really clunky, and the encounter rate is ridiculously high, to the point where I began escaping from most of the battles. Playing this way caused me to complete the game in just under 7 hours.

I do wish the game had ramped up the language-learning elements much more significantly. For example, it could have taught a lot more vocabulary and changed the dialogue entirely to Japanese when you get to Japan, which would have made sense thematically and been more educational. I also wish it hadn't taught words in hiragana that should be in katakana, since that could instill some bad habits in first time learners.

If you can get past those issues, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game for absolute beginners to Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052314408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1630527210}

author: {'steamid': '76561198158395960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1629666643}
review: Played all the way through. I have to say it actually helped me. I can distinguish Hiragana character a lot better now. But could you just practice them on your own and do fine without playing this game. Yes. But it kept me engaged. It more then just teaches you all the hiragana, you do learn new word and later on a few phrases. I will admit the pacing of the game is slow especially in combat when your looking for the right characters. But overall it feels like an RPG maker game. Price point is good. Nothing too special with the story. If in the end you improve then that's a plus and that's what the game is for. A side note, near the end make sure you're taking notes. It will come in handy for the final boss fight and dungeon. Or maybe I'm just slow at learning new words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198995814447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1632574356}

author: {'steamid': '76561198804319575', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1629338828}
review: Such an amazing game! Genuinely works, only played for 95 mins tonight before sleep and have already learnt so much its crazy, a good little method that's worked for me that might work for others is to create little pictures in your head to help memorise the hiragana, so for example for KU if you use your imagination a little you can see a person leaned over, so i imagine it looks like somebody about to sneeze so they're going KU KU and then once they sneeze they become GU and it almost looks like they've sneezed with the dakuten marks looking like the snot flying through the air xD, then for every hirigana i have my own image and it helps me remember so much! definetly will be playing a little every night then will edit this review by the end, if the devs do ever read this a good idea could've been when using support moves to ask a question like in the quiz that if you get right then add bonus healing points when the support is used to reward the player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013068021', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1093, 'last_played': 1469836017}

author: {'steamid': '76561198056327431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1716, 'last_played': 1628567466}
review:
I have studied Japanese on my own for many years. I bought this whole game series just for the Kanji study. But, I decided to start with Hiragana as a refresher. This game is one of the best learning tools I have seen for Japanese. Almost all of the major Japanese learning courses ignore things like dakuten and handakuten. This course covers ALL the hiragana. Also, I loved the challenge of learning the reverse hiragana. And, the emphasis of hiragana stroke order with animations is excellent.  I love how it explains using particles, such as WA is written as HA and E is written as HE.

Also, the study or Japanese words was great.

My only complaint is that the game makes learning a bit clumsy.  On the other hand, I was able to complete the game in 3 days. And, this game punishes you for not getting the translations right. So, it forced me to learn the hiragana characters that I have always struggled with.

Now, I am moving on to Katakana and Kanji versions of the game. Those ones are much more difficult for me!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995316499', 'num_games_owned': 764, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1627719677}
review: Fun way to learn hiragana. Addictive grinding is effective for memorization. The game also has some vocab and very basic sentence structure. Pair it along with flashcards and writing practice and you can learn this character set well in under a week.

review:

No es suficiente como para jugar simplemente y asi aprender, hay que estudiar y dedicar el tiempo necesario a tomar apuntes  y repasar por fuera del juego si de verdad queres aprender.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006408054', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1625623961}
review:
I greatly over estimated how much I would need to understand in order to play this game. I thought that I'd need to know the basics before diving in, and it turns out this game really is for beginners with little to no knowledge at all of Hiragana. For that reason, because I pre-loaded with my own studies beforehand, I'm not planning on continuing the game, but I do intend to start the others (Katakana and Kanji) before I get into those lessons through other source material. I managed to snag all three on sale, so it was somewhere around $5 for the three games, so I'm really not upset that I'm dropping this one.

Overall, if you are just starting out, it seems like a great game. The RPG seems a bit slow, and since it starts out at the [i]very[/i] beginning of Hiragana, I wish there was some sort of proficiency test to speed the story along to where I wanted to be rather than relearning the basics all over again. When the villain showed up and I understood the very basic greeting and parting that he gave, laughing maniacally the entire time that I couldn't understand his strange speech, I knew I was in for a bit of frustration. The lessons are neat, but I wish they didn't have such fancy letters for us to copy and something more modern, because I'm certainly not using a brush, so the brush strokes don't need to be there. There are a lot of battles in order to progress the story, and that's all well and good if I needed the lessons. Since I didn't, I found it tedious and I don't want to sink my time into trying to catch up to what I need to learn. Perhaps a training area to test your skills before you set out so you can just pick up where you need to be rather than walk here, walk back, walk over there, walk back, learn a new lesson, walk around some more and face soooo many encounters because you have to trigger each next step before the next lesson.

I'm giving this a recommended rating [b]FOR BEGINNERS[/b] or for people who need the opportunity to drill the sounds. I really wish I hadn't been intimidated with the possibility of being thrown into a game I wouldn't understand, because then I could have actually put some time into this one. But I was, so I rendered the game useless with my very basic studying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080422715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1634697232}

author: {'steamid': '76561198429481300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1628296748}
review: it's grindy but i think that's a good thing.  I ended up having to go back in between lessons to defeat the previous enemies and it's a good review/drills the symbols into your memory through pattern recognition.  Will it stick long term?  Not sure, but so far it's taking me less and less time to recognize the character and attack.  I should say that I've tried to learn Hiragana before so it might be helpful to supplement what you learn with some online flashcards, but even without that I think this is a very innovative way to learn and i'm pleased with it :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198140856835', 'num_games_owned': 2025, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1625215543}
review:
[Pay$-to-Play] We~W, I've completed the game after 15 hours of gameplay~
so, you can expect this game to be about 10 hours long if you are earnestly learning from it
To get the most of out this game, prepare a notebook and pen to jot down the words and practice writing them down

Right now it is 90% off so I've bought this game at less than a dollar with 10+ hours of gameplay, its definitely worth the money if you are seriously keen to learn Hiragana as the game element makes it engaging even for a lazy person like me :P

[h1] What to expect from this game: [/h1]
-[b]In this game, you will learn the equivalent of "ABCs"[/b] and thereafter you will learn to form words with it
They will teach you so&so character stands for C, so&so character stands for A, so&so character stands for T so eventually you will be able to form words e.g. C+A+T = CAT

- This game will teach you how to write and pronounce the Hiragana characters

- I've learnt about 71 Hiragana characters and 70+ nouns

Last but not least, It is an introductory to Hiragana characters so you wont immediately be proficient in speaking or understanding Japanese, nevertheless they have thrown in some common phrases & vocab / nouns  so there's other takeaways from it ^_^

Tags: [Learning] [JRPG adventure-like] [No achievements] [Repetitive so you can commit to memory]

author: {'steamid': '76561198291595359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1625117301}
review: This game is honestly a good and affordable way to learn hiragana. Pairing this game as well as continuing my studies on rosetta stone has significantly improved my reading, writing, and pronunciation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115885159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1625041359}
review: After dropping out of Japanese class in high school because I couldn't grasp reading Hiragana has always held me back from trying to properly pick it up. Many many MANY years later I have finally successfully begin to understand Hiragana. Sure it has some flaws, the lady who is speaking Japanese is clearly not a native and the battles are repetitive but being repetitive actually helped me to ingrain these characters into my brain. I bought this at 90% off and I must say this is money well spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561199169456620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1626388971}
review: Hiragana Battle actually makes learning hiragana fun. I was getting overwhelmed trying to learn the characters on my own. This game presents 5-10 characters at a time, and then you battle them by guessing what the correct pronunciation or Romaji is for each character after a lesson. The beginning of the game was very cheesy, but the game play itself is fun. It is turn based combat with characters whose weapons you can pay to upgrade at a weapons shop, etc. The fighting style is like Pokemon or early Final Fantasy games, as you walk around and are randomly attacked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153069268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1710521012}
review: I think it does very well what it sets out to do: make you remember hiragana. Through loads of repetition. The learning part of the game is pretty well made in my opinion and well spaced out. I would have liked to have the possibility to hear the characters pronounced more often (during the fights and not just during the lessons) and I think it would have been a lot easier to be able to "type" the answer during fights instead of having to select it from a (long) list. Also, I think there was a bit of a missed opportunity with the vocabulary section: learning only words that could be composed with the characters already learnt at that point would have been nice. But, considering I did not expect to get any vocabulary with this at all, I am still impressed. The gameplay and plot are quite basic but enjoyable enough to keep me coming back to learn (or refresh in my case) the next batch of characters, which is kind of the whole point. I was glad for the little side quests, which add just a bit of variety (and vocab). I have used it as a refresher, and I think that made it a little less interesting for me (knowing the characters already makes you want to skip the battles quite often), but I would totally recommend this as a learning tool for someone who is starting out with Hiragana. Probably not best on its own, but definitely as a complementary tool. The tips on how to write the characters that are given during the lessons were very nice and I had not seen that before on other learning tools I have used. I have purchased this at a discount price (the series bundle for 1,75€ or something like that) and for the amount of material it covers, I think it was a steal. I am looking forward to trying out the katakana (which I am rusty at, since it is harder to practice it) and kanji sequels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158945336', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1623781232}
review:
Super jeu pour apprendre les bases.

L'apprentissage des caractères se fait étape par étape tout en suivant l'histoire. On peut également voir un peu de vocabulaire de base et quelques concepts de grammaire. Il y a également des quêtes secondaire pour apprendre d'autres mots de vocabulaire.

Vers la fin du jeu le japonais devient de plus en plus présent car les noms de certains objets sont écrit en japonais et certains PNJ commence leur phrase par un mot ou une phrase en japonais qui est relativement simple mais qui est une très bonne idée.

Le jeu n'est pas extrêmement compliqué mais sa grande force c'est qu'on retient plus facilement les caractères à force de combattre (que ce soit de donner la lettre correspondante à l'hiragana ou l'inverse).

On apprend également certaines phrase de base très utile et on a la possibilité d'écouter chaque son, mot ou phrase en boucle.

Je trouve que c'est jeu est un must have pour débuter sans rester focus sur un livre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023836949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1623484532}
review:
I started learning japanese about 2 weeks ago.

To me this is a huge help since writing all the characters on my white board over and over again or going through textbooks can become a bit of a chore and take away the excitement or fun.
So every now and then when i feel like i don't want to go my usual route of learning i go to this and still do something for my studies.

Don't get me wrong it won't make you speak japanese magically. You still gotta learn for hours almost everyday (if you are like me, i do 1 or 2 hours max a day and when i work only 1 hour) but still.

I do like it a lot and i am having fun while learning new characters and other stuff that is in the game.
Also bought all the other games just because i know someday i might need them even tho that will probably take years for me xD

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198033926362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2302, 'last_played': 1658429309}
review: I really liked this game, learned a lot, and enjoyed learning Hiragana. Wanted to learn Japanese for a long time now, and this definitely motivated me to learn more outside the game. Definitely going to try Katakana war and Kanji Combat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198339307810', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1551925606}
review:
A friend recommended this game to me when I was starting out with Japanese, and erm...

It wasn't that good, to say the least.

I feel like I would have learned faster studying the kana through a chart than a game that depends on how well you're progressing through this RPG.

I expected the pacing would be faster than this, but it just felt so slow to learn all of the kana. I wanted to get to a point in the game where I can go against the Japanese words, because that's what I wanted to learn from this game the most, but that was so far out of reach for me. It just felt slow trying to get to that point, so I just dropped the game. One flaw I recognize is that no matter how well you recognize the first batch of kana during that section, it will still come after you with a high encounter rate, which is annoying, because you already know it at this point! and sometimes they would paralyse you to where you can't even answer that kana. Paralysis in this game sucks, and it's a terrible thing to add in a learning RPG game if you're familiar with it already.

You're better off using Duolingo or something else that isn't this tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054798873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1621165989}
review:
I bought this game to drill Hiragana, and I would not recommend it for for this purpose, or for learning hiragana. The progress through the game in terms of being able to defeat monsters is not in line with the player's ability to recognise hiragana reliably. Even when I recognised all the hiragana so far 100%, I had to go back and grind to level up and buy gear so that I could progress in the game.  The combat menu is a chore to use, as you have to select the correct hiragana transliteration from a huge list by using arrow keys. I am a beginner, but I managed to spot a misspelling, as well as some errors in explanations (eg a 'sidequest' that informs the player that 'desu ka' is the question part of the sentence, while in reality'desu' is the verb 'to be' and 'ka' is the question marker). Would not recommend unless the only way you can motivate yourself to learn hiragana is to do it in the form of a mediocre RPG.

It's not great as a learning resource and it's not fun as an RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198830983145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1620735920}
review:
Fun little game that helped me sit down long enough to actually learn all hiragana.
As the game went on they could've maybe mixed up the battles a bit more so you dont exclusively get in battles with the new set you just learned, and it would have been nice to have some more of the 'alternate dimension' battle area's where you get the sound and have to find the matching character, but all in all, a nice game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055963690', 'num_games_owned': 1947, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1620592046}
review:
TL;DR: Play this if you want to learn hiragana, don't if you don't.

A kind of reluctant recommendation here - the battle system is very basic, the way you select your attack would seem much more intuitive if they were set out in a table rather than two long lists, the levels are small and the encounter rate is correspondingly high (so if you're going from one end of a shack to the other you'll have five or six battles while crossing the room - only to be sent back to the side you came from, and *then* sent back and forth and back again, resulting in thirty or so battles just to get through one room).  Even getting all the attacks correct, the small amounts of damage taken adds up to you running out of healing items and MP if you use them.  Every time you visit the shop you've got to go through the same dialog on entering and leaving.  

HOWEVER... the repetition does help you learn, which is the point of the game.  And it provides a teaching tool that no-one else seems to provide - I can't say "play [x] instead" as there isn't any real alternative.  There are welcome little moments of humor.   You can just escape battles if you want - though that defeats the learning-by-repetition aspect of the game.  

It's helping me learn, which is why I bought it.  I just was hoping to have a little more fun while learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394206335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1619992096}

author: {'steamid': '76561198409808223', 'num_games_owned': 943, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1618931641}
review:
慢慢玩了八个小时左右通关了

在Learn Japanese To Survive-Hiragana Battle！的设定中，异世界被从日本穿越而来的法师Noburo带领的平假名军团入侵了，只有知道这些平假名正确的念法才能将他们打败，同是日本穿越而来的Misaki为了拯救这些平民，传授Snowleaf镇三个勇敢的孩子Claire, Eric, Leon平假名的念法，最终带领他们战胜了平假名军团以及Noburo

从头玩到尾的话可以记住全部的平假名，如果还做了所有的任务的话，还能学会150个左右的常用日语单词和句子。

游戏里的战斗机制是选择正确的平假名发音才能对怪物造成伤害，由于要刷钱、做任务，以及走各种迷宫推进剧情，所以游戏里的战斗数量很大，只要不跳过太多的战斗，[b]通关游戏后不仅能记住这些平假名，而且还能对平假名较为快速地辨识。[/b]

最终boss战不是选择平假名，而是从那一百多个常用单词选择正确的意思，可惜这部分比较短，因此那些单词记得就没平假名牢固了。

游戏虽然只有英语，但是难度很低，基本初高中生水平就能看懂大部分剧情了。考虑到游戏曾经多次进包，只要两三元的价格就能入手，性价比很高，[b]对于想学日语，但是怕枯燥 怕自己记不住的人，这个游戏绝对是个很好的选择。[/b]

我这就去通关第二部片假名的游戏。

author: {'steamid': '76561197972223919', 'num_games_owned': 1463, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1617418209}
review:
Great beginner introduction to Hiragana and very basic Japanese! Two weeks ago I knew a handful of words and literally no idea how Japanese words or sentences were formed. The repetitive nature of classic RPG combat works perfectly for memorizing and testing that memory.

I coupled playing this with copious amounts of Duolingo and frequently found myself wanting to come back to Hiragana Battle for its teaching structure which felt more natural as opposed to Duolingo's focus on quizzing.

Be sure to take notes! Writing things down helps immensely with memorization, and late in the game you'll probably be happy you have them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017805839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1642576720}

review: I really enjoyed playing this game it was a lot of fun. Though I knew roughly 80% of what I was taught it was a great refresher for my mind and pronunciation skills and I enjoyed learning at my own pace. Very useful tool in studying Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026549373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1620040225}

author: {'steamid': '76561198162672291', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1615032212}
review:
A forgetable rpg first and learning tool second.

The rpg part is another iteration of the old-school style rpg, fully functional, nice to the eyes if a bit clungy. Unfortunately, the learning part doesn't mix well with the rpg part. I tried the game twice, once knowing nothing of the japanese language, the second having learn about the difference and usage of hiragana, katakana and kanji and more or less having memorize hiragana. Both time I stopped after after around 1h : the first time because I was forgetting the kana of the previous lessons during grind sessions and feel I was missing context, the second because the kana part was simple enough that I was left playing an average rpg for 5/6 of my time and I have rpgs I like more in my steam list if I just want to play. Plus the vocabulary use romaji for all the kana you haven't see yet, so I was discovering the basic vocabulary without the hiragana. 

If you really like old-school rpg, you can give it a go as a side learning tool, else pass your way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154098985', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1639749017}
