author: {'steamid': '76561198126477602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1602187590}
review: I think it's a great game to learn the basics of Japanese and really get your Hiragana down. i am only on lesson three but as someone who knows some basic Japanese this is really useful to practice and review and I am exited to continue to play. (^-^)

author: {'steamid': '76561198983873165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1596572219}
review:
Two things upfront: It's a Kickstarter-Game (which I didn't know) and I find it to be alright for a refresher. 

I learned Kana some 20 years ago for fun and this brought everything back on the Hiragana part. 
Overall, while pretty basic in almost every aspect, it's a fun little learning experience that doesn't outstay it's welcome. Of course, if you intend to learn it for actual usage, you'll need to keep going and the game offers you to go back to every lesson, even after you finished it. 

Pros:
- You can see the drawing of every letter and it's stylized counterpart, along with a soundbit to guide you to it's  pronunciation. 
- The music is not obnoxious and goes along well with the game. 
- Visually nothing special but pleasant to look at. I like the character-sprites and their animation. 
- You get basic phrases and words thrown in the mix you'd encounter in beginner courses as well. You'll probably recognize a lot if you ever paid any attention to anime, movies, series. 
- For difficulty you can utilize level-ups from sidequesting if the combat is too hard/tedious for you. I didn't find it difficult, but being able to speed things up at times is a nice qol-feature I appreciate.
- You cannot advance if you don't learn and remember. Less of a problem when you can simply look up things, but true to what a learning-game should be like.
- Characters are likable. Didn't throw me of my socks but I didn't dislike anyone. On top of that almost every NPC looks different from the next one. 


Cons:
- Basic features and little adjustability. Heck, you can't even turn it off in the menu. When you do  adjustments on sound, or turn the music off for a bit, it takes effect on the next screen. Things I would expect from a somewhat contemporary RPG-Maker build. I still wonder if I had ever made back into post-game Snow Leaf Village if I had Alt+F4'd out of the Kickstarter-Scrolling at the end...  
So, not state of the art by any means, but to be fair it never ever crashed, slowed down or froze on me. 
- The pronunciation bits are too quiet and sound clunky, muffled and chopped up, except at the very end for the basic phrases. Those are pleasant and actually sound what I would expect every sound clip to sound like. Budget issues, I guess. 

Overall it really does cover little but the Hiragana, but that's already apparent from the title. And they do make you aware of alternate script sytles and the like. Still, I can't get over how lacking I found the audio for the pronunciation bits... Then again, there are plenty of other online-resources and at the end of the day it will provide examples for beginners that don't have a clue how Japanese sounds like. 

Like I said I had fun and it worked well as a refresher, so a thumbs up from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182044218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1597536945}
review:
Ich habe vor vl einem Monat damit angefangen japanisch zu lernen und versuche seitdem auch über Anime, Videos von Muttersprachlern, Spiele etc. das Gelernte zu festigen/neues zu erschließen.

Zu diesem Zweck eignet sich das Spiel wirklich gut, ich bin froh darüber, es gefunden zu haben. Es zwingt einen die Zeichen/Silben immer wieder zu wiederholen und sie so gut zu festigen und das in einem motivierenden Rahmen.

Wie allerdings von einigen anderen Rezensenten angemerkt: Ich würde es eher als begleitende Lernhilfe nutzen, als nach dem Spielen zu glauben, man könne nun ausreichend japanisch. Die unterschiedlichen Fonts führen leicht zu einer Verwechslung/Probleme beim schreiben, wenn man die Hiragana noch nicht kennt. Außerdem wäre eine echte Stimme wesentlich hilfreicher gewesen, als die computergenerierte Alternative.
Edit: Die Musik musste ich nach einer Weile durch meine eigene ersetzen. ^^

Von dem Gameplay habe ich nicht allzu viel erwartet (bin vl zu einem Drittel durch damit), wurde aber positiv überrascht. Wenn man kein besonders ausgefeiltes RPG oder Kampfsystem erwartet, erhält man solide Kost, die sich nicht durchgehend anfühlt wie ein Lernspiel. Es gibt einige nette Nebenquests, welche dem puren "lernen" von Hiragana nochmal entgegenstehen. Im späteren Verlauf gibt es auch Kämpfe bei denen man z.B. von der Romaji-Umschrift die passenden Hiragana nennen soll, ich hoffe auf weitere Variationen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097669758', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1599926764}
review: Just started the game, but have been streaming it on Twitch as well as publishing a Let's Play series on my YouTube channel for it. A couple of friends have even purchased it, we're having a blast learning Japanese so far. Only a couple of lessons in but I'm super excited to learn as much as possible. I'm a fan of the way the hiragana are presented, in 5-character blocks and seemingly in the same vowel pattern (a, i, u, e, o). Makes for better familiarity. The music is great as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561198120878627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1595958189}
review: O jogo é uma ferramenta interessante para quem quer iniciar seus estudos de japonês. Ele vai te ajudar a memorizar o alfabeto hiragana, além de um conjunto de palavras para o jogador ir se acostumando.  Para pessoas que já possuem um conhecimento básico, este titulo, pode não tão útil como ferramenta de estudo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045396501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1597628502}
review: Great interactive way to learn the Japanese alphabet. There is a Katakana and Kanji game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983194702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1645494535}
review: i've been going at it for at least 4 hours total so far at the time of writing.  I gotta say, im really starting to pick up on this whole language thing.  I really enjoy the 5 at a time theme, its really working out for me.  i very rarely go back to my notes mid-session as i have been doing good on studying between sessions.  Something that has helped alot is going back to my notes before bed and sleeping on it! oh right, review the game.  super basic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049158639', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1594027997}
review: Если вы хотите начать изучать японский язык, то это один из лучших способов влиться в обучение. Игра не напряжная, иероглифы запоминаются, механика самая что ни на есть классическая для этого жанра. Рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561199067128448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1681859575}
review: I really love that the game teaches you the alternates ( " ) of the hiragana directly after teaching you that set. The books I studied would always teach it after the whole base hiragana, so they'd always be hard to recognize for me the sound that it would be meant to make- but this game makes it super easy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999837334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1595315969}
review:
This game is a good starting point for people who have no experience with Hiragana. If you want to learn Japanese grammar this game will not help you much. The game isn't very long and covers 10 main lessons, That work out to all 71 hiragana characters, 15 phrases and ~30 words. The side quests will show give you additional words( roughly 80), but usually only give the hiragana or romaji spelling for them, which is fine since by the end of the game you should be able to work out the other one.

The level design isn't very good and by the time you reach the end, going through the list of characters to attack becomes tedious and annoying.

The music is average, sometimes it can feel repetitive but for the most part it works for the game.

The story is probably the worst part of the game but I suppose this games whole concept is silly and a story could be hard to write for this. However, if you are hoping for an engaging story you definitely will not find it here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280691699', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1595120167}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive is, at its core, an educational experience. The constant, Hiragana-focused battles and the progression-based character/vocab/grammar lessons solidify this. While the developers could have shipped off a product that's only as deep as its educational merits, Sleepy Duck ultimately created a world and cast with substantial charm and humor (especially for an educational source). The game, alongside being fun to progress, is an excellent gateway into the endeavor of learning a new language. I would highly recommend using external sources, such as Tofugu and Realkana, to round out your educational journey. Good luck studying!

 this steam guide goes into more detail: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1573508156

author: {'steamid': '76561198010864450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1612023942}

author: {'steamid': '76561198321103661', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1605987978}
review: It's a great study tool if you like JRPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067817027', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1680292977}
review: Im going to start this off by saying I got this game mostly as a bit of a meme. However it is a surprisingly good way to learn the very basics and hiragana. I used to use guides online for learning Japanese and worksheets to memorize hiragana, however while I would learn them, I'd have a bit of difficulty retaining the information or would just see a wall of text and kinda just blank out. However because game has story sequences between lessons and has you matching the right hiragana to their English equivalents in any battle you're essentially forced to take a bit to absorb it in and slows you down, meaning that its much less information taken in over a longer period of time allowing you to actually absorb a good chunk of that information. For what I paid (a total of 3 dollars for the whole bundle of thse games from fanatical) it is a surprisingly good experience and actually ended up teaching me a few things. Even the game for 6 dollars is a good deal in my opinion solely for the reason of actually absorbing the information if you don't have enough discipline to not rush through it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407882457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1594241424}

author: {'steamid': '76561198099595833', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1594434934}

author: {'steamid': '76561198403950058', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1594044174}
review: 前期的战斗，能打就好好打，级数高了，装备好了（最后开箱子有四把神武），之后的战斗能跑就跑，节省时间。最后说一下，游戏里面的日语并不难，很多单词都是耳熟能详的，关键是激发兴趣。第九艺术嘛，从游戏中间也是能学到有趣的知识的。

author: {'steamid': '76561198104796136', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1593621131}
review:
You have to understand that this is a mere guide, since repetition is key to learn this, but it's still an RPG so it could be a bit boring.

I tried to play it several times but didn't have the right mindset to learn, just expected to magically know hiragana, but the last time something clicked. You must know that this alone isn't enough, it will give you some vocabulary and obviously the hiragana but you must put a lot of yourself, I did some practice outside of the game and know I can read hiragana; I can't understand a thing but is the first step.

The game by itself is a nice start but keep in mind that you'll have to practice and research on your own too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960598374', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1564546436}
review: Pretty fun game for helping with Japanese. Much better than expected.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993987330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1593961464}
review:
I personally find this game to be a great revision tool if you're into the classic RPG format. I find it to be very engaging as well as very entertaining. Having a pen and paper is crucial to playing this game as it's the kind of thing that requires a 'cheat sheet' of sorts to get through if you're not particularly adept at Japanese - in saying that, for some learners I would also recommend starting out by using the charts that help equate characters to pictures to help ingrain the characters properly.
In summary: perhaps this isn't the greatest of learning tools, but it's an absolutely brilliant revision tool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198387415449', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1593951700}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033760543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1646805597}
review: It is a great way to learn Hiragana! The lessons show you how to write it, how to sound it out, how to use it... and it makes it fun with the gaming aspect of saving the world! XD I love it and can't wait to finish the others in my attempt to become self-taught fluent in Japanese!

author: {'steamid': '76561198834500805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1593555959}
review:
Esta muy bueno el juego, lastima que solo este en ingles. 
Es una forma muy entretenida de aprender Japones. No solo enseña las hiraganas, tambien un poco de gramatica, bastantes sustantivos y algunas frases.
Explican muy bien como se deben escribir, como se pronuncia,

Es 100% recomendable para quien quiere empezar a estudiar nihongo, y no se le dificulta mucho el ingles. 
Espero que sigan haciendo mas juegos para mayor nivel.

Acotacion. Yo ya tenia un nivel de N4 de japones, en cuanto a ingles me defiendo bastante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198390983427', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1593984615}
review:
The game really does what it promises, at the end of the game you'll have learned all the hiragana alphabet and will also know a few japanese words. So if you're a begginer, I strongly recommend it.
Now, as a game, you'll need a lot of patience to complete it. The game has a VERY high rate of random battles/encounters. Sometimes you barely walk three steps and tadaa, another battle. I know the game wants you to fight a lot because those are the moments you most practice what you've learned during the lessons, but come'on, there could be 30% less battles and you'd still have to fight a LOT. So that's a big negative thing for me.

My final score for it is 6.8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198226791772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1579259729}

author: {'steamid': '76561198243947008', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1593399610}
review: This game has a great amazing soundtrack, good story and great for learning hiragana. I think it should not cost it's current price ($8.95 AUD). If you already can speak and read Japanese it's not a game for you. If you are willing to start learning this is where you should start learning. If I Were To Rate It, It Would Be ( 7 Out Of 10 )

author: {'steamid': '76561198169506667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1594411469}
review:
A few notes on possible improvements and my general thoughts.
1. This is an accessory to learning Japanese, the best way is probably by purchasing exercise books (I prefer Timothy G. Stout from Tuttle. You probably won't really learn Japanese as fast as you could solely by playing this game but playing it subsequent a session of self-study with an exercise book will hasten the process.
2. If you already have some knowledge of the Japanese writing system, the early game might be a little tedious. I recommend that the developers in future updates or products introduce a system that tests you first so you can play according to your knowledge level.
3. The gameplay itself varies. It isn't greatly in depth and the main focus does seem to be the learning of the language but I wonder if an RPG would be the best method. Perhaps there would be other designs that could function better. Maybe like Papers, Please where you're a bureaucrat or translator traveling through Japan and lending your services. Something of the sorts. Not to say it's uninspired but the gameplay feeling empty might attribute to players losing interest quickly. 
4. The gameplay is a little rough in the sense that there's illogical leaps where your character will answer a for the next hiragana following a hiragana that has already been defeated, thus answering wrong. Moreover, if the purpose was simply to learn Japanese, the gameplay could've been easier. It's not very simple to juggle winning the game and learning the language at the same time.
5. Some of the characters are really poorly written. The blonde guy is the stereotypical culturally insensitive gajin. Straight off the bat he's telling us he wants to learn Japanese to get it on with Japanese women. I thought the character was stupid and annoying. I am not learning Japanese to get it on with hot geishas but because it is an interesting language from an interesting country. Wish they had a different characterisation.

All things considered, a handy accessory to learning Japanese. It sure beats Du*Lingo, the ersatz tool for broke retards who will never learn the language.
If you want to learn Japanese faster, get this game and play it whenever you're through with your daily exercises. 

7/10, it kind of does well what it intends to do

author: {'steamid': '76561198976154203', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1593538461}
review: Very good for beginners like me for learning Japanese, very thorough and well-explained, i'll be looking forward to also be completing the game and learning much more of the Japanese language.

author: {'steamid': '76561198960826954', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1591463683}
review: it has helped me a lot, of course i studied besides just this game, but its more fun than just normal studying, definitely worth the .77 cad when on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198181907162', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1612722840}
review:
This is an awesome game to learning Hiragana; almost every Hiragana's pronunciation can be read from our native language or its dialects(E.G.: Telugu) but some of them are very tricky, for example, you can read あ, い, え, お from English language but what about 'う'? And the same reasons of し and ち;  and more, we also can discover the rules of pronunciation about the hiragana's muddy sounds like if you pronouncing が, ぎ, ぐ, げ, ご then you can't use your "Soft G" in English to pronounce it otherwise it will become じ and じぇ sound; and the vocabulary is very well, although it includes a small amount of words, however, you need to use these words to fight final boss because language is used to speak, not just only to remember words and phrases.
Points: 10/10 and 95/100

author: {'steamid': '76561198114185627', 'num_games_owned': 886, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1578450829}
review:
If you are looking for a creative way to learn and memorize Japanese Hiragana...
Then look no further!
Yes, the game is very repetitive and can be seen as grindy, but how much are
you really going to remember if it's not repeatedly shown to you? Think of it
more as a learning tool rather than an actual game and it works wonders.
It's a breath of fresh air from learning the Japanese characters in a book.

Overall: It's a great supplement to your Japanese learning. Get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991656952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1593945010}
review:
El juego esta genial. Las lecciones son un poco largas, pero es normal porque tienes que aprender antes de poder combatir/practicar lo aprendido. 

Las explicaciones de las marcas sonoras (dakuten), doble consonante etcétera son excelentes y con ejemplos de sonido, cosa que no conseguirás en ningún libro.

El vocabulario que te encuentras por ahí también esta muy bien, a veces no es vocabulario sin más para aplicar el Hiragana, sino que son palabras que encontrarás en la cultura japonesa y que de esta forma te van introduciendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044306395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1580375928}

i liked this game because it allowed me to read hiragana yes very e d u c a t i o n al

author: {'steamid': '76561197995217470', 'num_games_owned': 1301, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1592134191}
review:
Ok, first ignore my hours in the game ( kinda have a habit of leaving rpgs open )
So far I do think the game is solid, it starts out by teaching you the different Rows of Hiragana, and having you battle them, the one thing is I will recommend some supplementary flash card system, as the game have a bad habbit of only using new kana in the next area so the time before you ever get back to some of the earlier kana is a tiny bit too long, otherwise does the game slowly transistion from english over to using more japanese words and phrases written in hiragana, which is nice.

Overall I will recommend the game as I am enjoying it, but I would strongly recommend to suppliment it with 
http://japanese.lentil.com/

Hope this helps <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198165214562', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1599180875}
review: Not the most efficient, but a really nice way to get into learning if staring at flashcards is too intimidating. Not too helpful if you already know the basics, but real nice for someone who has no background or knowledge of hirigana

author: {'steamid': '76561198058709061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1589655037}
review:
Hiragana Battle is a pretty cool edutainment game !

If you want to start learning Japanese, this is a pretty good spot !
You CAN definitely learn all of that on your own, but I think making it a game makes it more enticing to learn everything until the end (it definitely helped me !).
This game will teach you Hiragana one row at a time, along with quite a few useful words (a lot of them at the end of the game) and even a bit of grammar at the end.
As for the learning part, it works great !

However as for the game part, well, it's kind of basic.
The story / writing is extremely basic, but does the job I guess.
The balancing of combat difficulty was also a bit of an issue for me (I mean purely the amount of damage taken/received, not your ability to answer properly lol).
At the beginning, battles are a bit hard but not too much, it then becomes kinda hard to really hard, but becomes easy again when you are introduced to the side-quest system.
It is a system where you can exchange points that you get by completing side-missions for 1 more level for all members in your party. They tell you it is optional and you can supposedly beat the game without this help, and for middle-game to the start of the end, you would go through hell but yes it might be possible, but I have no idea how you would beat the last level without it...
Also, the visuals are kind of basic, but I don't find this a major issue.
Although, this game always kept me by surprise by switching certain mechanics around to keep things fresh. I especially liked the mechanics of the final level !

The in-game timer tells me that I took about 11 hours to beat this game with all side-quests.

Quick note: The pre-bundled executable did not work properly for me, the sound was really weird.
Hopefully, you can run this game in any web browser (yes, this is an HTML5 game) by temporarily disabling some securities (--allow-file-access-from-files option for Chrome) and it works just fine ! I used a Powershell script to run Chrome with the option and pointing to the index.html file.
That is why my game time is so low on Steam, just ran the actual executable to get the cards.

Don't think about my comments on the gameplay too much though. It is a very cool educational tool, that I would definitely recommend to anyone !
Now, onto the second game, Katakana War, to continue learning !

author: {'steamid': '76561198030704251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 988, 'last_played': 1591849107}
review: So took about 16 hours to complete from a complete beginner and I have found it very useful. The RPG element is fun and the re is a nice simple story that keeps the lessons moving. By the end I could recognise all of the sounds relating to the characters and translate words into Romanii. Definately worth it

author: {'steamid': '76561198164196771', 'num_games_owned': 806, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1111, 'last_played': 1591824870}
review:
I learned Hiragana using this game. ありがとうございますせんせい

Playing the game isn't enough, but where it does well in how it spaces out the learning. Sure I could have learned the characters quicker, but I feel by slowing things down it has gone deeper in to my long term memory. I also filled up a notebook practicing each letter and writing out new vocabulary.

Now I'm on to katakana

わたしはがんばります

author: {'steamid': '76561198349773291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1602813740}
review: If you want a big fully functioning game for the sake of playing a game, this may not be  the one for you. However, the game does an excellent job of teaching hiragana. I had some basic knowledge of hiragana at the start. By the end of the game, I could read through a list of hiragana and be able to tell you which one was which and I could do it rather quickly. The combat is fun and the side quests are rewarding. All in all, amazing game to learn hiragana with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041499783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1591472020}
review:
This game does a great job introducing series by series the hiragana, then let you practice recognition: you face hiragana characters and must find their romaji equivalent to win. There's even a short part where you face the romaji transcription and need to find the corresponding hiragana.
Each time you learn a new set of hiragana, you can be assured that you'll face that set in the next area, but the game also does a good job to include other hiraganas from series you learned earlier as well.
I yet have to finish the game (I just finished the Mount Fuji part), but if I had one suggestion to make, it would be to have more of the part where you face the romaji transcription: it would help make the association both ways more easily. Still, the most important ie, know how to pronounce and read hiraganas is covered, so that's not a big issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975546362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1591032338}
review:
Has had a random freezing bug since release that the developers never fixed. Seems to affect some people and not others. Teaches in alphabetical order, and through repetition only; no mnemonics or exercises beyond rote "match the hiragana to the romaji" or "match the romaji to the hiragana."

This developer's other "Learn Japanese to Survive!" games are decent, the Kanji one moreso than the Katakana one. Avoid this one and use Heisig's "Remembering the Kana" to learn hiragana instead.

ぴーぴー　ぷーぷー

author: {'steamid': '76561198076910886', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1590888557}
review:
Considering that this game is designed to be a learning tool, there are actually 2 questions answered in this review. 

Is it a good game?
Is it a good study guide?

As far as a game goes, it's pretty weak. About an hour of extra grinding throughout the game in addition to just playing and I was able to one shot most of the enemies. Once I got to Tokyo, I had enough money to buy the best weapons and armor for all of my characters and the enemies couldn't hurt me for the rest of the game (about 1/3 of the dungeons). The combat is basic. You have a handful of spells that you will never use because killing enemies is faster. Your attacks are all just answering the Japanese (and sometimes English) characters that you encounter as enemies. That being the case, every attack is physical and only targets one enemy. However, as you progress, the amount of "attacks" you have to search through in the menu to attack gets to be very long. I found this tedious, but because it is being used as teaching tool, I understand why it was the way it was. The game crashes relatively often. I had a half dozen crashes over my 10 hour completion of the game and all of its sidequests. on top of that, there is slowdown in a few areas. I've noticed this type of thing with RPG maker games on a few different systems, from super high end to mid tier computer. It's some coding issue that some of these indy games have. It wasn't too common this time, but it was there. The config options are just bad. There are 4 audio sliders, of which only 1 does what you think it does and you only get 5 stages of adjustment, making things either way too loud or too quite. Music is there, but nothing special. Characters have no personality and motivations for villains are never covered. As a game, it's dull and boring.

As a study guide, I have mixed feelings about this. First off, I studied Japanese is high school many years ago and so I already have a very dated understanding of some of the vocab and the characters. I've forgotten most of what I learned so I wanted to use this game as a small refresher of some of the basics. For me, the learning of Hiragana was rolled out a little too slow, but for someone being exposed to it for the first time, I can see it being paced alright in that regard. However, the game also introduced some basic terms and phrases, but it did so slowly over the course of the game, then didn't test you on it until the final dungeon. So even if you were taking all of your notes, by the time they mattered, you likely forgot the early ones as the newer ones were more fresh in your mind. All of the bosses were just more of the same hiragana characters, so what I would have liked to see instead is that bosses would use those vocab questions and then give us more bosses so we could work on multiple aspects of the language at once. Some things, like phrases, were only introduced to help the player out in real life and had no impact on the game. This is fine and good, but I would have used those phrases a little more when it came to the sidequests. I also would have liked it you could select which phrase to say to NPCs to initiate dialogue. All in all, I think it works alright as a study guide, but it is nothing special. When I was learning, I printed off the romaji for song lyrics and then kept filling in the hiragana and later katakana until I was able to recognise which characters better. The advantage to doing this is being able to practise writing at the same time.

TLDR: If you think the fact that this is a game will help you learn Japanese as a complete beginner, then give it a try, but don't expect to get an interesting game out of it. For me, it wasn't a fun game to play and it wasn't a particularly effective study guide either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138139495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1589902273}
review:
Da es schon spät ist muss ich es kurz fassen, aber dieses Spiel und Lernprogramm ist mit Abstand derzeit das beste was man bekommen kann, um spielerisch in die japanische Sprache einzusteigen. Es sei gesagt dass ich auch mit Videokursen und Büchern gleichzeitig arbeite, diese Spiele aber vor allem für das Einprägen der Schriftzeichen gekauft habe. Ich besitze nämlich alle drei dieser Reihe: Hiragana, Katakana und Kanji, welche auch jeweils das Schriftzeichen-Set lehren. Die Idee ist simpel und gleichzeitig genial. Man nehme RPG Maker oder ähnliche Tools und baut ein rundenbasiertes Abenteuerspiel mit Helden und gegnerischen Schriftzeichen und bei dem anstelle der typischen Angriffsfähigkeiten eines Gruppenmitglieds die repräsentativen Laute in form unseres lateinischen Alphabets (Japaner nennen es Romaji) gewählt werden müssen. Ein Hiragana-A kann also nur mit der Nennung eines lateinischen A wirksam getroffen werden. Neben üblicher JRPG-Mechaniken wie Heilung, Stärkung, Rätsel lösen und Nebenquests und der gleichen wird das lernen und trainieren wirklich vertieft. Als JRPG Spiel lenkt es gerne auch immer wieder ein wenig in der nötigen Dosis ab. Ich hatte nie das Gefühl im Konzept eines Lernspiels oder im Konzept eines Abenteuerspiels unter- oder überfordert zu sein. Mal muss man ein Gruppenmitglied heilen oder in die Stadt zurück um seine Figur besser auszurüsten. Dadurch bleibt man, in meinen Augen, jedoch höchst konzentriert, zu mal beim Aufenthalt in der Stadt stets die Lehrerin angesprochen werden kann um alte Lektionen zu wiederholen. Die Lektionen sind in den Fortschritt/Geschichte eingeflochten und werden Stück für Stück langsam an den Spieler und Lernenden ran gebracht. Diese Lehrerin ist auch der Hauptquestgeber in der Storyline wo man von A,I,U,E,O bis WA und N wirklich alles an Hiragana lernt und trainiert. Zwischenzeitlich gibt es auch Vokabeln, Redewendungen und etwas Kulturinfo über Japan. Zum Teil auch sehr nett in Nebenquests verpackt. Recht spät im Spiel muss man auch die ersten gelernten Hiragana beim Lesen einer Shop-Liste verstehen um eine Nebenquest zu schaffen. Auch gibt es später im Spiel zwei oder drei kurze Abschnitte bei der hiragana-gegner umgekehrt abgefragt werden. Man muss dann die Romaji Gegenstücke mit einer Hiragana Antwort besiegen. Echt gelungen, und ich glaube ich hätte mir ohne dieses Spiel nicht so viele Hiragana am Stück gemerkt. 
Drei wichtige Anmerkungen: auf meinem PC war das Spiel recht absturz-anfällig. Ich rate jedem, alle 5 bis 10 Minuten auf einem oder mehreren Save-Slots zu speichern damit nicht so viel Fortschritt verloren geht, falls euch das auch passiert. Trotzdem rate ich zum Kauf des Spieles und Support des Entwicklers, denm von allen Games, die ich jetzt auf Steam und am Handy gesehen habe, ist dies mit einer so enormen Tiefe und Liebe gemacht wurden, dass ich nichts vergleichbares nennen könnte. Außer KOE das jahrelang in Entwicklung ist und gefühlt nie kommt. Und sämtliche anderen Spiele bzw Lernspiele wirken alle nicht vollständig oder sind am nötigsten Punkt eher unausgereift oder nicht so tiefgehend wie diese JRPG Reihe von "Sleepy Duck".
Die zweite Anmerkung sei noch, sich tatsächlich, wie von der ingame-Lehrerin gewünscht, Papier und Stift zur Hand zu nehmen und reichtlich Notizen zu machen. Einerseits lernt man Hiragana auch durchs Schreiben noch effizienter (Muskelgedächtnis) sondern auch deshalb, weil die einmaligen Vokabelnotizen (bitte in Romaji und Hiragana aufschreiben) später essenziell wichtig sind um einen bestimmten späten Story-Abschnitt meistern zu können. Passned zum Thema des Spiels wird der Endgame-Abschnitt recht knackig, wenn man nicht gut mitgeschrieben hat und keine anderen Schulmaterialien besitzt. 
Dritte und wichtige Anmerkung: Natürlich -nicht anders zu erwarten- ist das Spiel auf englisch. Einerseits wird der Entwickler wohl kein Deutscher sein, andererseits ist englisch eine internationale Sprache, und damit ist dieses Lernspiel international zugänglich. Und für die ewigen Englisch-Verweigerer sei gesagt: lernt Englisch, dann Japanisch :)
und Ja, das Spiel sieht etwas "alt" (retro, pixel-look) und klischeehaft aus, und selbst wenn man RPG Maker als Grundlage für so etwas nicht mag, so denke ich mir jetzt nachträglich: es gibt aber auch nichts und niemanden der es bisher schon besser gemacht hätte und damit am Markt wäre. Viele pixelige JRPGs, sogar bei den Konsolenplattformen, gibt es ja zu hauf. Aber kein einziges mit Sprachen-lernen als ernstes Konzept. Und es gibt auch nicht annähernd etwas vergleichbares.
Da ich den Hiragana-Teil heute "durchgespielt" und "durchgelernt" habe, werde ich demnächst mit Katakana weiter machen. Das Spiel dazu heißt "Katakana Wars" vom gleichen Entwickler. Angespielt habe ich es bereits und ich muss sagen es lohnt sich, denn die Spiele bzw deren Editor-Grundlagen, mit denen sie gemacht wurden, scheinen sich von Teil zu Teil weiter entwickelt zu haben. Nach Katakana und dem dazu passenden Spiel werde ich Kanji angehen, und auch wieder das dazu passende Spiel des Entwicklers laufen haben. Es lohnt sich in meinen Augen wirklich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043782587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 598, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1590169687}
review:
Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle prides itself to be a quality multimedia edutainment. What they, Majestic 12, don't want you to know is that it's neither a smart education nor a good entertainment.

Let me list the reasons:
Ladies and Gentlemen...
RPG Maker.


Which isn't to say that RPG Maker sucks as engine, for it gave an absolute awesome birth to OFF. But you know how years ago mentioning gaming engines was seen as showcase of graphics and powers yet in these years it just immediately brings picture of shovelware games into mind? Yea.

Ok, real list:
 - Every asset is RPG Maker stock asset. Aside from Hiragana, obviously. And I heard that the game had kickstarter.
 - Controls and interface and gameplay are all RPG Maker stock. Mouse users will sure to enjoy having to double click everything. And they didn't even include the exit game button anywhere. You will play the game forever and you will like it. Also, not a fan of RPG Maker MV version engine, it gives me nano-loading freezes whenever I go exploring into status menu.
 - The plot is cheese that nearly reaches a cringe level. Ebil wizard attacks your stock RPG town with Hiragana symbols that you can harm only with your Hiragana knowledge. Which would have been more fun if it was written in adult maybe self-aware, way. Then again, I want to strangle all the self-aware humor in 2020 and this cheesy plot probably allows kids to enjoy the game too.
- You would think that in order to reinforce Hiragana knowledge you will be shot many kana at high pace. Nope, devs took too much inspiration from JRPG of olde to the point where it doesn't fit. Each battle lasts like 30 seconds both because of slow unskippable animation and having to manually select the Romaji answer to kana from the ever increasing list of choices that doens't fit to a single screen and also leads mostly to patten recognition instead of direct learning and you will be sick of doing it for all 4 characters manually. At times battles last more than one turn which is pointless for learning. 
 - Enemies can apply status effects that seem at times to last only one turn and then normal combat lasts only like 2 turns so if you made use of antidote magic you just wasted a turn you dood.
 - If two characters gang on one kana but it dies in one hit, the second character will hit another kana with same, now wrong, answer, wasting your time.
 - There are only few preset sets of Kana squads you can encounter per area instead of being actually randomized, you will learn their patterns soon. Once again, more of pattern learning instead of directly learning. Gaming the system. Of course, I came here to learn Hiragana so I forced myself to remember the pronouncation of Kana first but you know, I brought a game and it should be a challenge that teaches you, otherwise you should just use flashcards and what not.
 - Developers didn't quite handle the intricate art of stats tweaking in RPG Maker. Once you get midway through the game when your characters will have like 100+ defence each, the game balance will be constantly hinging between whooping your ass and doing 0 damage.
 - Featureless mazes ahoy with no interesting things to explore, few misplaced tiles aside, that  make you run in circles while you pop enemy encounter every few steps that you have to grind, which I call grinding instead of learning reinforcement due to mentioned flaw of having only few preset kana possible encounters per area that you will exhaust real fast.
 - I have used the game along with unrelated book to learn Japanese but I must say that if you dedicate the whole game to Hiragana alphabet you ought to get real into it. Book says that in order to make long M in MA series of kana I should place N beforehand. Nothing like that in the game.
 - Combat where you translate Romaji into Hiragana was nice but too rare, should have made it common encounter.
 - The game teaches you vocabulary as a side content and I hate it. I am of a camp that believes that it's best to learn your words by translating texts and then reinforcing it with tests. Game here just randomly gives you separate semi-random phrases and words through a game out of context and then only reinforces that in the very final level, suddenly rushing down. I just tanked that part of a game through because I know that I will forget words in few days with this kind of teaching. Then again, the big idiot is me for tanking through game part I didn't like instead of watching walkthrough, heh.
 - Besides, you are supposed to remember words by their kanji (hieroglyphs) writing and I heard that devs made a mistake in Hiragana writing of at very least one word, so.
 - Lessons are so slow and clunky so I don't ever want to revise them. It's true that "study guides" you get as item are just a single screen but they lack info and you can revise vocabulary only at your femme sensei.

Overall, you are being sold real amateur RPG Maker project there and you ought to skip it. Hiragana is not that scary, you can do it yourself without gaming motivation that will just annoy you here.

It did help me to reinforce Hiragana memorization but then there are other ways to do it. I just had this game already purchased back when I was less grumpy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117981695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1147, 'last_played': 1589014342}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090208022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1588623365}

Especially challenging yourself by switching between identifying English and Japanese letters. Studies aside, it was actually really fun and had a decent story line.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986283507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1588565916}
review:
This is a less boring way to learn Hiragana characters. That being said, there is room for improvement to increase the enjoyment of the game, as well as for learning purposes.

If I could make changes to the game, it would be this:

* Reduce the number of players in the battle. You spend most time selecting which "attack" (answer) to use, and most of the time you use all the players to attack the same enemy (logically so). Since there is no tactical advantage changing up the attacks, having multiple characters attacking the same word multiple times seem pointless (see my second recommendation for how it possibly could be solved).

* The attacks quickly become boring. The idea of having to select the words matching the hiragana is brilliant, but it does not feel like a good game. If we could mix in a few elements of Final Fantasy, say adding spells and attacks such as "Fira Ka", "Fira Ki", (...), "Quick Attack Ka", and so on, with abilities that could be unlocked as we go (as you do with each lesson), it would feel more rewarding. Each attack with different colors and effects to make the game feel less mundane, and make each attack stand more out.

A way to go about this would be to have a Spell type, Physical type, and possibly a Status type for every character. "Fira Ka", "Slash Ka", "Sleep Ka", depending on the character. This would change how you play, by using the different characters to actually affect the flow of battle.


------


If you are completely new to Hiragana, this game definitely wont keep you entertained while learning all the way. This would be best played in short sessions (perhaps once a day, every other day) while learning a set of characters. Even then, you will have to grind a bit to be properly adjusted, in order to battle the stronger "Hiragana Warriors".

Would I recommend this to learn Hiragana? "Yes, but". I would not recommend this as the sole way of learning Hiragana. This is a supplement. A way to practice without making it feel like a chore (which is very good). Just keep the sessions short, no more than perhaps 20-30 minutes (perhaps that is too long), to avoid getting bored. 

-----

tldr; A good way to supplement your learning. It is simple, perhaps too simple, which can make it boring in the long run. Play in short sessions to keep it more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968302441', 'num_games_owned': 1771, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1588500519}
review: Learn Japanese words, match them up with the enemy to do damage to them, if you get the word wrong then you won't do any damage. It's that simple.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009517770', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1605943444}
review: I just finished this game and while there are probably more efficient ways to learn Hiragana, I think that Learn Japanese to Survive - Hiragana Battle at least makes the process engaging and meaningful. I'd recommend you play with bikke the pirate's guide in the Guides section of the game on Steam. I'd also recommend trying to memorize the vocabulary before finishing the game because it will help in the end. You have to do the side quests to acquire much of this vocabulary, so do them all before completing the game. I think daily practice using something similar to the Real Kana app and website will help. You won't learn to speak Japanese from this game, but it will set you on the path to be able to read Hiragana which will help you in that journey. Best of luck! I can't wait to try the other games in this series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088431876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1590412662}
review: It does what it says it does. It helps you learn Hiragana, and it's just Final Fantasy enough to make it worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034776999', 'num_games_owned': 1468, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1588892145}
review:
Não é um jogo complexo desenvolvido por uma mega desenvolvedora, é um jogo simples, mas até cumpre o que é proposto, vai ser uma analise bem direta ao ponto.

Como o nome indica é focado na parte do Hiragana, eu venho estudando o idioma faz um tempo, mas ainda confundo alguns símbolos. Esse jogo funcionar como aqueles Cards que você usa pra estudar. Pra derrotar os inimigos que são, adivinha o que, Hiraganas você precisa selecionar o som/escrita tradicional referente ao Hiragana que está enfrentando. 

A história é bem bobinha, sobre um bruxo que usa magias em Japonês e por isso você precisa entender o idioma pra derrota-lo, mas enfim.

É bem simples o jogo, mas com o tempo você vai memorizando e realmente aprendendo. Obviamente esse jogo você vai usar como SUPORTE não como a ferramenta principal, eu estudo  usando sites como o Memrise ou videos no Youtube mesmo, sempre anotando no meu caderninho e esse jogo você vai usar mais pra tentar revisar o que está aprendendo.
É um jogo de RPG maker, então é tudo bem simples e pode se tornar monótomo pra algumas pessoas, então tenha isso em mente.

Ele é bem baratinho, com um dinheiro de sobra você pode catar, no meu caso eu ganhei em um SteamGifts da vida.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028405707', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1588474794}
review:
I've been using this game to supplement my learning of hiragana and it has really helped a lot. Do not rely on it entirely, include it into your studies instead. 
Personally I will practice whatever hiragana I will be learning next outside of the game by way of brute force learning. I visually memorise the hiragana until I feel I have them nicely remembered. Then I will boot up the game and follow its handwriting tips on a practice sheet. When it comes down to the battles I have that practice sheet squared away so I can't reference it and I haven't lost a battle yet. The battles are a great way to recall what you have learned. 
I try to aim for one new line of hiragana a day and this game really does speed that up.

So yeah, don't rely on this always use as many devices to learn as possible, but this one does help a lot! 

Other things I have been using to learn are listed below:
- Practice Sheets: http://japanese-lesson.com/characters/hiragana/hiragana_writing.html
- A good and customizable quiz: https://kana.pro/
- Tofugus mnemonics list: https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-hiragana/

Enjoy and happy learning

author: {'steamid': '76561198351988718', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1588558583}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008367456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1819, 'last_played': 1587504582}
review:
it did realy helped me to start learning Japenese.
But,
Has a game designer and level designer a saw 2 principale problem all along the game and a small 1 at the End.
1 The enemy partern.
I found out that the enemy patern was extremly repetitive inside the same biome. What i mean is that I pass throught a full chapter without ever encountering lot of hiragana that was the principale studies of that same Chapter. exemple: You learn the H b and P groupe. During the encounter for that exact 3 groupe I never saw must of the P and never I saw any ho, bo or po. In another exemple At a rediculous ratio of 60% chance i was encountering di which is very rare to use in japenese (acording to the person i know that know Speak Japenese)
Solution: making That the % rate of spawning a pecular Hiragana increase every time that you don't see it.

2 No retro study
So when you get in a new Chapter you learn new Pool of Hiragana wich is perfect. During that chapter you will mustly encounter those Hiragana (which is perfect). THe real problem is that i never saw a pool of Hiragana of 2 chapter prior to the chapter i was. 
Solution: 
Actual Studied Hiragana Spawn Ration: 60%, all the others 40%.

Solution 2:
 to fix both first problem would be to put enemy into the world map. Those enemy pool should be all the Hiragana Studied yet.

Problem 3: 
The End Game.
The game is quiet nice. Ultra charming (that is what kept me playing instead of starting to study without it), have a nice Story. Basicly the problem is that i don't fell confident enought to go after a bigger fish with my actual skill. A end Game thing to help to study more instead of buy the Katakana Battle game can be nice.

review: Awesome stuff. I'd tried learning hiragana before, but without the practice and a fun way to make it stick, it always failed so thank you! author: {'steamid': '76561197994346855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1586718187}
review:
My actual in-game playtime for this game was about 24 hours.  I spent quite a few hours learning to write and read Japanese Hiragana characters while the game ran in the background.  

The learning part of this game is very light.  They show you how to write each character, give you a brief description, and tell you how to pronounce it.  You will then get a small quiz after each lesson.  The RPG part of this game is also fairly light.  There is not much depth to the characters, and using abilities aside from attack and guard is almost pointless.  I was able to one-shot almost all of the enemies in the game because I kept my level as high as possible, and I made sure I upgraded equipment as soon as possible.   Very standard old-school JRPG kinds of stuff.  

You will however, be in for a world of hurt if you don't either memorize everything, or at least write everything down in a notebook.  Also, you should keep the vocabulary lessons in a completely separate section from the Hiragana lessons.  This will come in handy throughout the game.  

Overall, the adventure is fun, and I love that I learned something about speaking and writing Japanese in the process.  I recommend this game if you are considering learning Japanese as an additional language.  It will give you a taste of what you're in for, and show you if you really want to learn the language, or move on to something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168346778', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1586602572}
review:
I tried to learn Hiragana in the past, but I couldn't find the proper technique and motivation. This game helped with both.

As far as a learning game goes, it worked well for me. The more you fight, the better you memorize the different hiragana and can read them more easily. One problem I had with it was the font used for them during battle. Sometimes it differs a lot from the font in the text, which can be confusing.

However there's a problem with the battle system. It's hard to explain it, but the way the attacks and valid targets work, as long as you have assigned more than one hero to fight an enemy and the enemy dies with the first strike, the second attack will be lost. This prolongs the battle and forces you to attack the remaining enemy next turn.

The game itself is not without flaws as well. In the second half there's an elevator door that's supposed to open so that you can progress in the game. Except that usually it won't. I got stuck there for a while and had to look up the solution. You have to leave and re-enter the building a couple of times, until the elevator decides to trigger.

This educational game seems to be inspired by games such as "Lufia 2 - Rise of the Sinistrals". The chests look very similar, especially the beautiful blue ones. And they had the same concept of focused energy as a weapon.
The story is easygoing and rather fun. There's a limited selection of equipment, armor and weapons. It features surprise attacks and ambushes as well as status effects. The later don't really matter, since they only last a round or so and the normal battles never took more than two.

As for the playtime, I'm a slow learner and I spent a lot of time grinding "levels" and "money" - but in truth I just needed and wanted the practice. It took me 21 hours to finish and I probably wouldn't mind replaying it at some point, just to refresh my knowledge.

Oh, one more thing. Do yourself a favour and write any word down that the game teaches you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988999542', 'num_games_owned': 1080, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1613651330}
review: Finished the game and great at teaching how to pronounce read and write Hirigana. Think pokemon battles but fighting letters instead. I personally think repetition is great for learning and that is exactly what happens in battles. It shakes the letters up a bit but I am getting to a point early on where I recognise without having to think about it as much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005329310', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1586377938}
review:
First of all, while this is a game, it is intended as a tool to learn Hiragana first.
I've finished the game in about 13 hours, within 3 days. I think I managed to memorise about 90% of the lessons in the game.
I strongly recommend approaching this as a class more than a game. The battle elements are like homework : you get presented with a character, and you give your answer to that character. You get it right, you damage it, otherwise you do nothing. I have hand-written the characters maybe a hundred times each to commit them to memory, and did not use a cheat sheet for battles (but I would write all enemies as if I was asked to write them down for an assignment).
The battle system is more than basic. After a while you can one-shot most enemies until the next lesson, ailments all wear off after battle, and enemies can't damage you that much if you get equipped. A little more depth, better UI, and more variety would have been welcomed. Often, you won't encounter much of the previous lessons' enemies in newer areas, which means that if you want to study them you need to go back in older (and laughably easier) areas. Still, there are a couple of nice surprises, but they're mostly in the last areas.

If you are not serious about learning the Hiragana alphabet, this is not for you. It is simple, but it expects you to study on your own, maybe even without the game open.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042537843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1586193790}
review:
This game has helped me learn half of the hiragana characters in less than 5 hours. It's not the only resource you need, as I've also been using flashcards, but it's extremely helpful in getting you to recognise the characters. 
The game elements are enjoyable, although I admit it wouldn't be worth playing were it not for the educational aspect. I don't think that's a negative thing, however - because if you're not interested in learning Hiragana, you wouldn't be playing this game anyway!

author: {'steamid': '76561198326212462', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1498584227}
review:
Es un buen juego pedagógico para el aprendizaje de los caracteres básicos, vocabulario y ciertas cuestiones gramáticas esenciales. La temática RPG lo hace un juego ligeramente interesante, aunque la historia no es muy profunda. Es un juego que recomendaría si te encuentras interesado en comenzar a aprender japonés, es un buen acercamiento al idioma, pero si lo buscas principalmente por una buena historia, jugabilidad o por gusto a los RPG no sería una compra recomendada, ya que podría resultar aburrido para quien no se encuentre interesado en el idioma japonés.

Por cierto, este juego tiene su secuela que es sobre el sistema de escritura katakana y una tercera de los kanjis básicos para un nivel JLPT 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205401179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1682178999}
review: Bon jeu pour apprendre les hiragana nous mettant dos au mur avec un système de jeu typique des vieux RPG japonais ! Je conseil d'acheter le bundle avec les 3 jour pour apprendre tous les "alphabets" japonais

author: {'steamid': '76561198067490221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6621, 'last_played': 1584893173}
review: Great game that teaches you the Japanese syllables but at the same time says it has few exceptions to how you learn but as you find out there is a lot of exceptions. A lot of characters that mean the same thing but are just specific to say pronounce/write-out something/someone. Japanese takes 900 hours of study and I've played this game over once before and when I started again a flood of memories and characters I have yet to study again reappearing in my mind. So it does do a good job and making you memorize the characters. Learning all the different words the Japanese culture has to offer is up to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198954448241', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1632208175}
review: great one for who never learned japanese

author: {'steamid': '76561198082128011', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1583636772}
review:
Si quieres aprender japonés pero eres demasiado flojo como para estudiar en serio, este es un buen juego... bueno, al menos para empezar.
Memorizar los hiragana es un poco complicado si no tienes las ganas necesarias para repetirlos hasta aprenderlos correctamente, en cuanto a eso, este juego presenta un modo en el que terminar memorizándolos sin darte cuenta mientras avanzas en los combates. Por supuesto, no es recomendado evitar combates y es muy buena idea intentar conseguir todos los objetos que entren a tu vista, no para hacerte el juego más fácil o algo, sino que para practicar un poco más.
En general, por el precio es un buen juego tanto para entretenerte un poco o para aprender los hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198427390684', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1582564430}
review:
Okay. I generally have a rule not to review games I haven't fully completed yet. But I MUST write this review now, because I need to emphasize very important points of this game as someone who learns Japanese by himself. I will give this game a negative review for now (it may change in the future, I can't say this for sure). At this very moment, I like this game in general. But it has VERY serious issues when it comes to [b]teaching[/b] kana.

This game is perfect if you are searching for an educational game which is good for drill exercises. We'll talk about this later. But I have several pretty big questions about the lessons.

In each lesson we have a set of kana characters (one row from gojuuon table + (han)dakuon, if available). The first issue comes from the presentation. What we can see on screen is the calligraphic (printed) representation of the symbol from embedded Japanese font. It's being used both here and in the gameplay. But when the player asks for the animation to learn how to write this symbol on paper, these two versions (calligraphic and animated handwritten) do not match. It's natural, since we do not write letters exactly as they are printed in the book, but it creates a problem. When we are being asked to practice this character in our notepad what we can see on screen is the calligraphic version, not the handwritten one. And I, personally, couldn't understand from looking at my monitor, how exactly I am supposed to write it. BTW, [b]I know[/b] how to write these - I'm in no way a complete novice in learning Japanese, I considered this game being a nice short practice for me. But this is what confused me from the very beginning.

The second issue is the hints for writing. I couldn't understand from these hints whether I'm learning [b]calligraphy[/b] or trying to practice my [b]handwriting[/b]. Because some of these hints are useful for the former, but not for the latter. Also, to develop a consistent handwriting you need 1) an [b]exact sample[/b] of the symbol, it's usually presented inside a square 2*2 grid so you could understand the proportions and relative position of lines; 2) a working sheet with the same grid to practice (you can use checkered notepad or notebook); 3) hints for positioning of your hand (Japanese and Western styles of writing are different!). None of these are being featured here. The DLC study guide has the printed and handwritten versions of the character on the same page, though, but that's all. Oh, and also I want hints like how not to mix up some characters which are pretty much identical (I'm constantly reading あas お and vice versa).

The third issue. We are being constantly reminded about the order of strokes in kana characters. But it's probably a common question for everyone who is learning Japanese. [b]Why the order of strokes is important?[/b] It could be outright inconvenient for some people to write these symbols the way they are supposed to be written. For example, when we write Western letters (Latin or Cyrillic ones), we usually write the "body" of the letter and then add something, like diacritics. So why it's important to write kana and kanji in Japanese exactly like this? Here it's a question without an answer. I want at least a brief explanation of this, like: 1) When you write fast, wrong stroke order could make your handwriting incomprehensible, or you could easily miss a stroke and turn, for example, あ into め or き into さ or something; 2) When you'll start to learn kanji and their keys/radicals it's very important to write these [b]fast[/b], and fast cursive handwriting will be absolutely indecipherable with the wrong stroke order; 3) The stroke order is important in handwritten input for the right recognition of characters; ... Well, you got the point.

The fourth issue. You must not use a robot for voiceover in teaching! The right pronunciation is very important in Japanese and similar languages, and the voiceover must be done by a native speaker.

The fifth issue. The vocabulary, which is pretty out of place. I understand that you have to provide examples of the words with these kana characters just explained. But could you choose the words a bit more wisely or consistently? For example, do not mix romaji and kana in the beginning. It will improve the effect from learning greatly.

The gameplay. As I said, this game is good for drill exercises, when you repeat the same characters over, and over, and over, and over... The battles with the "enemy" kana characters (vulnerable to the right guess of its pronunciation) are literally every dozen of steps here. Also, it's good for training to recognize kana visually [b]for reading[/b] (but not by ear, it's not really relevant, but it could be a nice addition to write words in kana by ear). The gameplay itself is your mediocre "educational" story made in RPGMaker, the RPG element isn't really deep or something, it's more like it does absolutely everything to make the game longer. Which is understandable (longer gameplay - more enemy encounters), but sometimes just plain boring (the locked door is on the one side of the labyrinth you just went through, the key is... you know where). And it becomes bad when the RND doesn't work at all. I was forced to play the same battle with the same three enemy characters [b]three times in a row[/b]. I'm supposed to know 25 characters already, what about the other 22?

upd: And another thing which pretty much annoyed me here is that EVERY single menu button in this game must be pressed twice to work! First time for highlighting, second time for activating. It could be a legacy of RPGMaker, but seriously, what the...?

The game actually has nice hints and some basic trivia about Japan for everyone who is learning Japanese. It's useful, really. It's entertaining, and it's good. But if you want to actually [b]learn[/b] kana, not just for reading and understanding these characters in texts (this game is perfect for this task), but for using it yourself, then it will be much better to find a free kana course in Google, print materials and use these for actual learning. I used materials from one of these sites (I won't put the link here, since it's not an advertizing, but you can find it easily on first page by searching "free hiragana self-study course") and there are really good hints and examples for handwriting along with short examples with pronunciation on YouTube. And really, it was much better for me.

-----

If you are interested in other games I'm playing, check my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36682541-Lonely-Dev-Reviews/]Curator page[/url]. Maybe there will be something good for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995782746', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1582370614}
review:
Can it help you to read and memorize hiragana better? Absolutely. Especially if you try to complete all side-quests and to get the best armour and weapons in the game, you will have to grind a bit. And battles the same subset of hiragana dozens of times will commit their shapes to you memory like nothing else. 

Positive:
- It has exactly the right length, a 100% run will only take about 6 hours
- The visual are nice, nothing extraordinary, but pleasant to look at with no style clashes. The sequel is better, though.
- The mazes in the dungeons are not overly complicated. It's a learning game first, and a RPG second.
- If you complete every side-quest and try to grind just enough money to buy the best equipment you will have no difficulties whatsoever, the RPG part of the game becomes trivial. Your progress only depends on how well you can recognize hiragana, which is exactly the right gameplay approach for a learning game.

Negative:
- The music just OK. The battle theme kind of sucks which is a pity because you will hear hundreds of times. The sequel got this MUCH better.
- The battle system has built-in flaw. You have to provide commands for all of your characters at the beginning of a round and only afterwards the round starts and the commands are executed. Since your attack only damage enemies which exactly match your attack choice (hiragana) as soon as an enemy is killed and you have another character left attacking with the same hiragana the attack will randomly shift to the next target for which the chosen hiragana won't match (there are never more than one enemy of the same kind in a battle) and the attack will be wasted. This was fixed in the sequel.

RECOMMENDED.





Negative:

author: {'steamid': '76561198076296740', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1580365056}
review:
So this is gonna be a long in-depth review of LJTS-HB. Ill add a TL;DR at the end but this is gonna summarize my experiences and what I believe are pros and cons of the game.

So an overall summary of the game is that as a SIDE learning tool, it is really helpful. I am usually terrible at learning new things and maintaining the information, especially languages (took a German class 5 years ago and only remember like 5 words, but I remember the alphabet because its the basic 26 + 4 more letters) so learning all brand new 46 characters is and still somewhat is a tough thing for me. With the game being at a somewhat slow pace and playing about 45 minutes to an hour per session for me, it really helped me out with not being such a fast learner. I enjoyed the same from the beginning to about roughly to the end (Explained later in cons section)

[b] Pros [/b]

+ Good pace(for slow learners): If you have a hard time retaining information and/or don't have all the time in the world to study, this game is a good pace for you.

+ Study guides: The game has included study guides so in case you are having trouble with some characters, you can go back and re-learn a set of characters if needed. I personally never used it but I feel like if I ever needed to then I would have used it to better reinforce it to my memory

[b] Neutral [/b]

+- Story: the story is nothing AAA but that isn't what you came for here, it was to learn. The story is at least better than average In my opinion but not 100% memorable.

+- Side-quests: same thing with story, they are not terrible. Majority of them are just learning words in hiragana and that's it. 4-5 will make you fetch/buy items to then learn words. I THINK that probably 60-65% of the words you learn are not average day words that are used in a typical day in Japan. Also more of a con than a neutral, but side quest knowledge isn't implemented into the gameplay at all which sucks, but then the game would have been more difficult for non-side quest players so I understand.

+- Visuals: Nothing too special here. The game is created in RPG Maker so most interfaces and assets are nothing too special in my opinion.

+- Grind: Like most RPGs and JRPGs, there will usually be a time of grind. I will say out of my 8 hours, probably 30-45 minutes were spent grinding for levels and yen. I beat the end of the game without the highest tier armor because I would have probably had to grind for 1 hour or so, but at the end everyone was LV. 30+ which is enough to beat the game

[b] Cons [/b]

- Battles: While I can say that the battle do help you remember and put the characters in your long-term memory, the fights are not 100% random. From KeyofW's Review, the battles are predetermined 2-3 hiragana sets in each area, so basically just need to learn the combinations to remember what characters are in what group. The game as well said by KeyofW should have had a more flexible system that could have had 100% random encounters.

- Ending: So I will say this as the game will tell you this, but DO WRITE EVERYTHING IN THE LESSONS DOWN! While that seems like a no brainer thing to help you remember the hiragana, some lessons teach you words, which I don't see that as wrong, but 'SPOILERS' the final location of the game, [spoiler] the hiragana warriors you face are the words that you learn in the lessons. The final area took me an extra 30 minutes to complete because I had to re-look at my book that I was writing things in almost every fight to remember what combination of hiragana is what words. It felt very tedious and while I could look and say "yeah I know the hiragana" I couldn't remember what word they made. [/spoiler] Probably just a me thing but it really made the ending not the best for me.

So to summarize everything I just wrote: The game isn't the worst tool to use, but it could have been better in some aspects. I will take the knowledge I learned from this game and use it as a secondary tool for me to help remember the hiragana. I currently own all the games, thanks to a bundle, so my next game to play is the Katakana one so I might do a review of that one once I beat that, but I'm gonna drill the hiragana into my head for a while so I have this info in there and I don't have to keep looking up characters from time to time.

[h1] Overall score: 6/10 [/h1]

TL;DR: For a secondary tool, not a bad choice. good pace for slow learners, average story, but not the battle system or ending.

Update (3/7/2020): Lowered the score due to after playing Katakana War and at first rating it a 8/10, I realized that was a bit too high for what it was so lowering that to a 7 and this a 6 because in comparison that game was better in some aspects.
